PAGE WAS INTENTIONALLY LEFT BLANK) BDM Section 100 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 1-1 SECTION 100 – GENERAL INFORMATION 101 0BINTRODUCTION 101.1 35B DM FORMAT C101.1 Where the BDM is written in two-column format, the left column represents ODOT structural design specifications and the right column represents commentary. The commentary may include background information; design guidance; or other supplemental information related to a corresponding specification item. Where the BDM is written in full page width format, all content represents ODOT structural design specifications. ODOT structural design specification items shall apply unless the Owner provides a waiver of the item in writing. The design values, specifications, practices, etc. established in the BDM promote uniform, safe and sound designs for bridges and structures in the State of Ohio. During the normal staged review process, the Owner has the authority to require the Designer of Record to justify or otherwise seek recommendation from the Office of Structural Engineering (OSE) when deviation from the design values, specifications, practices, etc. is necessary. 101.2 36B DM AUDIENCE C101.2 The requirements of the two-column format ODOT Bridge Design Manual (BDM) are written to the “Designer of Record” as defined in BDM Section 101.4. The sentences that direct the Designer of Record to perform work are written as commands. For example, a requirement to design bridges for HL-93 loading would be expressed as, “Design all bridges for an HL-93 loading,” rather than “The Designer of Record shall design all bridges for an HL-93 loading.” In the imperative mood, the subject, “the Designer of Record” is understood. All requirements to be performed by others have been written in the active voice. Sentences written in the active voice identify the party responsible for performing the action. For example, “The Office of Structural Engineering will review designs for non-standard bridge railings.” Sentences that define terms; describe a product or desired result; or describe a condition that may exist are written in indicative mood. These types of sentences use verbs requiring no action. For example, “All reinforcing steel shall be epoxy coated.” 101.3 37BPURPOSE C101.3 The BDM establishes ODOT policy for the following: A. The analysis, design and rating of new and existing bridges. B. The analysis and design of new and existing retaining walls and noise walls. C. The analysis and design of new and existing pedestrian structures. BDM Section 100 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 1-2 Consider the practicability of construction with reference to each detail of design. Constructability is especially critical when new ideas are considered. 101.4 38BCOORDINATION WITH CONTRACT DOCUMENTS C101.4 Ohio Department of Transportation bridge designs shall be in conformance with the following publications listed in descending order of precedence: A. Scope of Services B. ODOT Bridge Design Manual C. ODOT Location and Design Manual, Vol. 1, Location and Design Manual, Vol. 2 & Location and Design Manual, Vol. 3; ODOT Traffic Engineering Manual; the ODOT Pavement Design Manual; ODOT Geotechnical Design Manual, and the ODOT CADD Engineering Standards Manual D. Proposal Notes and Special Provisions E. Supplemental Specifications F. ODOT Construction and Materials Specifications G. AASHTO LRFD Bridge Design Specifications and AASHTO LRFD Bridge Construction Specifications Other ODOT bridge design publications (e.g. Standard Bridge Drawings, Design Data Sheets and Plan Insert Sheets) become ODOT structural design specifications when required by reference from any of the publications listed in BDM Section 101.4. Where complete description or instruction is not provided in the C&MS, provide the description or instruction in the plans to ensure clarity both from a structural and contractual viewpoint. 101.5 39BTABLE OF ORGANIZATION An organizational chart for the various sections in the ODOT OSE and a list of bridge contacts is available on the office’s website. 101.6 40BABBREVIATIONS AASHTO American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials ADT Average Daily Traffic ADTT Average Daily Truck Traffic AISC American Institute of Steel Construction AREMA American Railway Engineering and Maintenance-of-way Association ASTM American Society for Testing and Materials AWS American Welding Society BDM ODOT Bridge Design Manual CADD Computer-Aided Drafting and Design CLP County Log Point C&MS ODOT Construction and Material Specifications CVN Acceptable Charpy V-Notch impact testing of steel material is required BDM Section 100 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 1-3 DBT Design-Build Team DEC District Environmental Coordinator EPA Environmental Protection Agency FHWA Federal Highway Administration GDM Geotechnical Design Manual published by the ODOT Office of Geotechnical Engineering IZEU Three coat steel coating system consisting of Inorganic Zinc primer coat, Epoxy intermediate coat and Urethane finish coat. Typically used for new steel members. L&D ODOT Location and Design Manual LRFD Load and Resistance Factor Design. When used in combination with AASHTO, this refers to the current edition of the AASHTO LRFD Bridge Design Specifications. References to specific AASHTO LRFD sections throughout this manual will be italicized (e.g. LRFD 11.10.5) MSE Mechanically Stabilized Earth. Typically used as earth retaining wall systems. NCHRP National Cooperative Highway Research Program NDT Non-Destructive Testing ODOT Ohio Department of Transportation OES Office of Environmental Services OES-WPU Office of Environmental Services – Waterway Permits Unit OHWM Ordinary High Water Mark OAC Ohio Administrative Code OMM ODOT Office of Materials Management ORC Ohio Revised Code OSE ODOT Office of Structural Engineering OZEU Three coat steel coating system consisting of Organic Zinc primer coat, Epoxy intermediate coat and Urethane finish coat. Typically used for existing steel members. PID Project Identification Number PN### Proposal Note RGP USACE Regional General Permit for ODOT projects impacting Waters of the U.S. S#### Supplement SFN Structure File Number SGE Specifications for Geotechnical Explorations published by the ODOT Office of Geotechnical Engineering SLM Straight Line Mileage SPP Special Provisions Package SS### Supplemental Specification STD Standard Temporary Discharge TAF Temporary Access Fill TEM Traffic Engineering Manual USACE U.S. Army Corps of Engineers USCG U.S. Coast Guard USGS United States Geological Survey VECP Value Engineering Change Proposal BDM Section 100 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 1-4 101.7 41BDEFINITIONS Bridge – The ORC 5501.47(B)(1)(c) defines a bridge as any structure of ten feet or more clear span or ten feet or more in diameter on, above, or below a highway. Refer to the Ohio Bridge Inventory Coding Guide for more specific information. Bridge Limits – The distance between the bridge ends of the approach slabs measured to the nearest hundredth of a foot along the Centerline of Construction. Centerline of Construction – The reference line used for construction of a project. Normally located at the median centerline on a divided highway or at the normal crown point location on an undivided highway. Checker – The Checker is an individual employed by the Design Agency responsible for ensuring correctness, constructability and completeness of designs detailed in the Contract Documents. Contract Documents – Refer to definition provided in C&MS 101.03. Culvert – Unless otherwise noted, a culvert shall be defined herein as a buried structure type, regardless of span, placed on, above or below a highway. Design Agency – The firm, partnership, association, limited liability company, government entity or corporation that employs the Designer of Record in accordance with ORC 4733. Design Loading – The envelope of load factors and load combinations encompassing the permanent and transient loads acting on the structure as required by the governing design specifications. Designer – The Designer is an individual employed by the Design Agency responsible for preparing designs detailed in the Contract Documents. Designer of Record – The Designer of Record is the individual that professionally endorses (signs and seals) the design in the Contract Documents in accordance with OAC 4733-23-01(C) and as specified in the L&D, Vol. 3 Section 1302.6.1. Haunch – The distance between the top of a beam/girder and the bottom of the deck. Invert – The bottom or lowest point of the internal surface of the transverse cross section of a pipe or conduit Normal Water Elevation – Water elevation within a waterway produced by groundwater flow and not influenced or minimally influenced by surface water runoff. The Normal Water Elevation shown in the plans is approximate and will fluctuate seasonally and from year to year. Ordinary High Water Mark – Defined by the USACE Regulatory Letter No. 05-05 which is available at: www.usace.army.mil/Missions/CivilWorks/RegulatoryProgramandPermits/GuidanceLetters.aspx.This elevation marks the jurisdictional limit of the USACE. Owner – The Owner shall be defined as the duly authorized agent of the government agency sponsoring the project. For ODOT sponsored projects, the sponsoring District shall be considered the Owner. Pedestrian Structure – A structure which is designed for and intended to primarily carry pedestrians, bicyclists, equestrian riders, and light maintenance vehicles, but not designed for and intended to carry typical highway traffic. Proposal Notes – Specifications that supplement and supersede Supplemental Specifications and the C&MS. Project Manager – Individual selected by the sponsoring agency responsible for advancing the project through the development process. Refer to ODOT’s Project Development Process Manual for specific duties. BDM Section 100 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 1-5 Reference Line – A chord drawn from centerline to centerline of abutment bearings at the Centerline of Construction or an extension of a line tangent to the Centerline of Construction at the centerline of abutment bearings. Rehabilitation – Title 23 Part 650 Section 403 of the Code of Federal Regulations (i.e. 23 CFR 650.403) defines “Rehabilitation” as the major work required to restore the structural integrity of a bridge as well as work necessary to correct major safety defects. Examples include: deck replacement, fatigue retrofit, structural patching, bearing replacement and railing upgrade. Reviewer – The Reviewer is an individual employed by the Design Agency responsible for the overall evaluation of the design in the Contract Documents for completeness, consistency, continuity, constructability, general design logic and quality. Skew angle – The skew angle is the angle of deviation of the substructure unit from perpendicular to the centerline of construction or reference chord. Supplemental Specifications – Specifications that supplement and supersede the C&MS. Supplements – Individually numbered documents describing necessary information such as laboratory test methods and certification or pre-qualification procedures for materials. Temporary Access Fill – A fill or structure that allows a contractor access to work on roads or bridges located within bodies of water. Examples of TAF’s include: cofferdams; temporary structures for maintaining traffic; causeways and work pads; and demolition debris. Thalweg – The line defining the points of lowest elevation along the length of a riverbed. Also, commonly referred to as the Flow Line. 102 1BPREPARATION OF PLANS C102 Draw all detail views to a scale large enough to be easily read on 11-in x 17-in sheets. Views shall not be crowded on the sheet and shall fit within the prescribed borderlines. Do not state the scale of the views on the drawings Reproduction of the drawing prints may distort the scale resulting in inaccuracies. Place a North Arrow symbol on the Site Plan, General Plan and all plan views. The north arrow is useful for orienting field personnel using the plan and may eliminate possible construction errors. Show Elevation views of piers and the forward abutment looking forward along the stationing of the project. Show the rear abutment in the reverse direction. Detail rear and forward abutments on separate plan sheets for staged construction projects or for other geometric conditions that produce asymmetry between abutments. When describing directions or locations of various elements of a highway project, use the centerline of construction and stationing as a basis for these directions and locations. Number sheets in the bridge plans in accordance with BDM Figure 102-2. BDM Section 100 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 1-6 For structures on a horizontal curve, provide a Reference Line. Show the Reference Line on the General Plan/Site Plan view with the stations of the points where the Reference Line intersects the curve. Provide skews, dimensions of substructure elements and superstructure elements from this Reference Line, both on the General Plan /Site Plan and on the individual detail sheets. Do not providing dimensions from the curve. Dimension the distances between the curve and Reference Line at each substructure units. The purpose for dimensioning the distance between the Reference Line and centerline of the substructure units is to make a check available to the contractor. For each substructure unit, show the skew angle with respect to the centerline of construction or, for curved structures, to a Reference Line. Measure the skew angle from the centerline of construction or Reference Line to a line perpendicular to the centerline of the substructure unit or from a line perpendicular to the centerline of construction or Reference Line to the centerline of the substructure unit as shown in BDM Figure 102-1. Figure 102-1 In placing dimensions on the drawings, provide sufficient overall dimensions so that it will not be necessary for a person reading the drawings to add up dimensions to determine the length, width or height of an abutment, pier or other element of a structure. Do not show a detail or dimension in more than one place on the plans. Unnecessary duplication increases the risk of errors, particularly where revisions are made at a later date. If, because of lack of space on a particular sheet, it is necessary to place a view or a section on another sheet, provide cross references on both sheets. Define all abbreviations in a legend provided on the General Notes sheet. Plan sheets shall be 22-in x 34-in. Margins shall be 2-in on the left edge and 1/2-in on all other edges. Keep design and check calculations neat and orderly. This provision allows for calculations that are easily followed and understood by a person other than the preparer. 102.1 42B RIDGE PLAN PREPARER QUALIFICATIONS The Design Agency shall be prequalified in accordance with the “Consultant Prequalification Requirements and Procedures” published by ODOT’s Office of Consultant Services. BDM Section 100 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 1-7 102.2 43BCOMPUTER AIDED DRAFTING STANDARDS For drafting standards, refer to L&D, Vol. 3. 102.3 44BDESIGNER, CHECKER, REVIEWER INITIALS BLOCK Provide individual Designer, Checker and Reviewer initials and the date of the final review in the title block of each sheet. 102.4 45BTITLE BLOCK C102.4 See BDM Figure 102-2 for an example of bridge plan sheets. The Office of CADD and Mapping provides MicroStation cells for bridge plan sheets in the OHDOT_Sheets.cel library. Provide the project name in CO-Route-Section format. Show the Section as SLM to the nearest 1/100 of a mile. Example: MUS-70-10.49 Provide the bridge number as defined in BDM Section 905. Example: MUS-00070-10.890 A Station is defined as 100-ft. Show Stations to the nearest 1/100 of a foot. Example: STA 895+08.75 Show the correct SFN in the Existing Structure Block and Title blocks for the existing and proposed structures respectively. The SFN for the existing structure should be included in the Scope of Services. If not, it may be obtained from the Owner. If a new SFN is required for a proposed structure, contact the Office of Structural Engineering, Bridge Management Section. It is the Designer of Record’s responsibility to contact and confirm the correct SFN with the appropriate office. Provide the PID below the project name in the Title Block. Include the name and address of the Design Agency in the Title Block. BDM Section 100 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 1-8 Figure 102-2 BDM Section 100 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 1-9 102.5 46BESTIMATED QUANTITIES C102.5 Provide plan quantities separately for each bridge SFN. Do not incorporate common bid items between multiple bridge structures in a project. Summation of common items cannot be done due to computer tracking of quantities based on Structure File Number. Furnish electronic files of the structure quantity calculations in accordance with the L&D, Vol. 3. Prepare neat, accurate and complete quantity calculations on standard computation sheets. Arrange the calculations in an orderly fashion so that a person examining them will be able to follow the calculation sequence. Someone other than the original Designer shall independently check the calculations. The Designer and Checker shall each prepare separate sets of calculations to minimize risk of error. Reconcile the two sets of calculations and select one set (either the Designer's or the Checker's) as the official set. Both the Designer and Checker shall initial and date each sheet of the calculations. The results of this official set shall correspond to the quantities shown on the plans. Since this information may be useful to contractors preparing bids, the Department provides it as a courtesy at the time of advertisement. This information is not considered part of the bidding documents and is for information only. Provide the Bridge Number; SFN; the date; the individual Designer and Checker initials; and subject on each sheet of quantity calculations. Sheets that are accidentally misplaced are sometimes very difficult to identify if they do not contain this information. 102.6 47BSTANDARD BRIDGE DRAWINGS C102.6 Where required by the Scope of Services and/or BDM, follow current Standard Bridge Drawings. Provide reference to Standard Bridge Drawings using the Drawing Number and latest date of revision or the approval date if there has been no revision. If standards are not adequate for a particular design, then modify the standards, as necessary, by supplying pertinent details, dimensions or material specifications in the plans. Standard Bridge Drawings provide common details and requirements for structures in Ohio. Most of the drawings require fully detailing the items in the plans to provide clear and bid-worthy plans. The Designer shall be familiar with the standards and know if they are adequate for the particular design situation being addressed. Standard Bridge Drawings can be downloaded from ODOT’s Office of Structural Engineering website. Reference Standard Bridge Drawings on the General Notes sheet and the project plan’s Title Sheet. Do not reference a standard drawing if only one or two small details on the standard are applicable. In such instances, include the required details in the project plans. Do not reference more than one standard drawing for a individual bridge component. Reference to a standard drawing when very little of the drawing applies to a project can be confusing and lead to contract disputes. 102.7 48BSUPPLEMENTAL SPECIFICATIONS C102.7 Supplemental Specifications are specifications that supplement and supersede the C&MS. Supplemental Specifications are available on ODOT’s Division of Construction Management website. Modifications to Supplemental Specifications require plan notes and “As Per Plan” pay items. BDM Section 100 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 1-10 List Supplemental Specifications, like standard bridge drawings, on the General Notes plan sheet. (See BDM Section 600). List Supplemental Specifications referenced on the General Notes sheet on the project plan’s Title Sheet. 102.8 49BPROPOSAL NOTES C102.8 Proposal Notes are specifications that supplement and supersede Supplemental Specifications and the C&MS. The Department’s numbered Proposal Notes were developed to assure uniform specifications for specific items that may not be required on every project or are either experimental or of an interim status. Proposal Notes are available on ODOT’s Division of Construction Management website. Do not revise Proposal Notes. Reference Proposal Notes in the table of Estimated Quantities by adding a note to the end of the applicable bid item (See Proposal Note). Do not refer to Proposal Notes by number. Ensure the Proposal Note is only specified where applicable. 102.9 50BSPECIAL PROVISIONS C102.9 Special Provisions are project specific specifications with the same order of precedence in the Contract as Proposal Notes. Provide the title and date for all Special Provisions on the Title Sheet of the Plans. Consider converting General Notes that are lengthy such that multiple plan sheets would be required into Special Provisions. 102.10 51BSUPPLEMENTS C102.10 Supplements are individually numbered documents describing necessary information such as laboratory test methods and certification or pre-qualification procedures for materials. Do not reference Supplements in the bridge plan General Notes or the project plan’s Title Sheet. Where necessary, Supplements are referenced as needed by the C&MS and Supplemental Specifications. 103 2B RIDGE PLAN SHEET ORDER C103 A set of completed bridge plans shall conform to the following order: A. Site Plan B. General Plan – A General Plan sheet is required for any of the following:

  1. Bridges with variable width and/or curved alignment
  2. Bridges with staged construction 3. Bridge deck overlay projects The purpose of the General Plan sheet is to provide bridge information that can get lost in the clutter of information typically shown on a site plan. The General Plan sheet does not require an elevation view. C. General Notes D. Estimated Quantities BDM Section 100 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 1-11 E. Phase Construction Details F. Abutments G. Piers H. Superstructure I. Railing Details J. Expansion device details K. Non-standard approach slab details L. Concrete Reinforcement Bar List 104 3BSTRUCTURAL REVIEWS C104 The purpose of a review for each of the Structure Submissions defined in BDM Section 200 is to ensure compliance with a project’s Scope of Services. If a Structure Submission is required by the Scope of Services, do not omit a compliance review of the submission from the Project Development Process. Upon request of the Project Manager, the Design Agency shall provide project records including, but not limited to: design calculations, software files, survey data, and project correspondence, in a timely manner. The Design Agency shall provide to the Project Manager, a written response for every review comment provided in a Structure Submission. The Project Manager will provide a copy of the written response to each compliance reviewer. The project shall not proceed to the next stage of the development process until the Project Manager is satisfied that all comments have been resolved. Resolution of a Structure Submission does not absolve the Designer of Record from liability for Errors or Omissions. Ultimately, the Designer of Record bears the responsibility for the content of the design plans. Compliance with the Scope of Services means compliance with the following: all referenced contract documents; all defined aspects of the project; schedule; and budget. These reviews are not intended as a computational or analysis check of the contents of the design plans. However, the compliance reviewer may perform an independent analysis or request design calculations, software files or other project records, to verify that a design is compliant. For ODOT-let projects, the performance of the structural reviews is the responsibility of the District Project Manager assigned to administer the project. The Project Manager may: delegate the review to a technical expert at the District; request review services from ODOT’s Central Office; or contract review services from a prequalified consulting firm. The Department typically obligates at least a 30-day window from Stage Submittal to Stage Completion. Within that timeframe the Project Manager will transmit the submittal to various reviewers for comments to be addressed by the Design Agency and resolved to the Project Manager’s satisfaction. The Project Manager should be aware that resolution of review comments can delay a project’s Staged completion date. An acceptable Design Agency written response to a structure review is: “We concur with all comments except the following:” BDM Section 100 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 1-12 (THIS 2-31 BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-ii (THIS PAGE WAS INTENTIONALLY LEFT BLANK) BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-1 SECTION 200 – STRUCTURE SUBMISSIONS 201 4BSTAGED REVIEW PROCESS 201.1 52BSTRUCTURE TYPE STUDY 201.1.1 168BGENERAL C201.1.1 Where a bridge is the most appropriate structure for a particular site, then perform the Structure Type Study to determine the appropriate bridge type. Refer to BDM Section 101.7 for the definition of what qualifies as a bridge per the ORC. Study the project site in detail to determine the best structure alternative. Conducting a site visit is highly recommended. In many cases, it can be readily determined whether a bridge or culvert structure should be chosen for a particular site. Provide a separate Structure Type Study for each SFN on a project. For identical parallel bridges that require separate SFN’s in accordance with the Ohio Bridge Inventory Coding Guide, develop a full Structure Type Study for one of the bridges. The Structure Type Study for the twin structure shall refer to the full type study to avoid duplication of effort. The purpose for this requirement is to ensure that every bridge on a project receives an independent Structure Type Study. For bridges that do not require an SFN, a Structure Type Study is still required by the opening paragraph of BDM Section 201.1.1. At the approval of the Project Manager, an independent Type Study may be provided for the twin structure. 201.1.2 169BSUBMISSION REQUIREMENTS A Structure Type Study submission shall include the following: A. Profile for each bridge alternative, see BDM Section 201.1.2.11 B. Preliminary Structure Site Plan for preferred bridge alternative, see BDM Section 201.1.2.2 C. Hydrology and Hydraulics (H&H) Report, see L&D, Vol. 2. D. Narrative of Bridge Alternatives see BDM Section 201.1.2.3. E. Cost Analysis see BDM Section 201.1.2.4. F. Foundation Recommendation see BDM Section 0. G. Preliminary Maintenance of Traffic Plan, see BDM Section 201.1.2.6 Include the Structure Type Study in the review submission made directly to the District Office. 201.1.2.1 368BPROFILE FOR BRIDGE ALTERNATIVE C201.1.2.1 Draw the profile for each bridge alternative being considered to the same scale as the corresponding plan. This scale is the same as that shown for the preferred alternative on the Preliminary Structure Site Plan. The scales are to be the same for comparative purposes. BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-2 Include the following for each profile: A. Existing and proposed profile grade lines B. Existing ground line C. An outline of the structure D. Bridges conveying riverine streams or channels require the following hydraulic information:
  3. Cross-section of waterway channel 2. Highest known high-water mark
  4. Normal water elevation Refer to BDM Section 101.7 for Normal Water Elevation, OHWM and Thalweg definitions. Normal Water Elevation is an estimate of where the water elevation will be when not influenced by surface water runoff. Plan designer should establish the Normal Water Elevation from waterway physical characteristics and observed water elevations when surface runoff is minimal or not present. No recurrence interval runoff event corresponds to the Normal Water Elevation. The Normal Water Elevation will be lower than the OHWM elevation. The Normal Water Elevation, shown in the bridge profile view, provides bidding contractors with understanding of the physical characteristics of a waterway and that water is likely present even when no surface water runoff is occurring. Identification of the NWE, OHWM and design storm event water elevations provides information as to how the channel responds to varying occurrences of surface water runoff and can be critical in planning and bidding in stream work.
  5. OHWM
  6. Thalweg elevation
  7. Scour Information Examples of scour information would be scour history, scour holes, etc.
  8. Design and 100-year water surface elevations (WSE)
  9. Overtopping flood elevation and frequency Flood Insurance Studies use the 100-year flood as the baseline. Carry WSE in a FEMA Zone out to two decimal places E. Bridges conveying waterbodies that have controlled outlets or spillways require:
  10. Cross-section of the channel
  11. Summer pool elevation 3. Winter pool elevation
  12. Surveillance pool elevation 5. Record pool elevation
  13. Spillway elevation 7. Top of dam elevation Refer to L&D, Vol. 2 for more information related to these waterways. F. Existing and proposed profile grade elevations at 25-ft increments G Minimum and required vertical and lateral clearances. BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-3 H. Spans dimensioned as follows: 1. Spans on straight (tangent) alignments: measure from center to center of bearings along the centerline of construction.
  14. Spans on curved alignments: measure along the Reference Line.
  15. Spans for standard concrete slab bridges: measure from a line 1-ft behind the face of abutment substructure or breastwall. 201.1.2.2 369BSITE PLAN C201.1.2.2 The Site Plan scale shall be 1-in = 20-ft. For structures with bridge limits exceeding 400-ft, match-mark the site plan across multiple sheets at the same scale. For bridges where the 1-in = 20-ft scale is too small to clearly show the Site Plan details, a 1-in = 10-ft scale may be considered. The following general information shall be shown on the Preliminary Structure Site Plan: A. The plan view shall show:
  16. Existing structures (using dashed lines) 2. Contours at 2-ft intervals showing the existing surface of the ground (for steep slopes contours at 5-ft or greater intervals are acceptable)
  17. Existing utility lines and their disposition. Identify and accurately locate all utilities. Indicate the disposition of existing utilities (e.g. whether they are to remain in place, be relocated or be removed, and for the latter two, by whom). Avoid placing utilities on bridges where possible. The request to allow utilities on the bridge shall be made through the ODOT District Utilities Coordinator. Refer to the ODOT Utilities Manual. For specific detail requirements refer to BDM Section 310.4
  18. Proposed structure 5. Proposed temporary bridge
  19. Proposed channel improvements 7. North arrow
  20. Required minimum and actual minimum lateral and vertical clearances and their locations. For a bridge over a railway, the vertical clearance shall be measured from a point level with the top of the highest rail and 6-ft from the centerline of those tracks, or greater if specified by the individual railroad. Reference shall be made to Chapter 15, Section 1.2.6(a), AREMA Specifications for increased lateral clearances required when tracks are on a horizontal curve.
  21. All other pertinent features concerning the existing topography and proposed work. B. A profile as described in BDM Section 201.1.2.1. The profile scale shall be the same as the plan view. C. Horizontal and vertical curve data. D. Bridges conveying riverine streams or channels require the following information: BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-4
  22. Elevations described in BDM Section 201.1.2.1.D.
  23. Size of drainage area
  24. Design year flood frequency, discharge and velocity
  25. Scour Design Flood & Scour Check Flood 5. 100-yr discharge and velocity. Label discharge as “FIS” when taken from a FEMA Flood Insurance Study.
  26. Clearance from the lowest elevation of the bottom of the superstructure to the design year water surface elevation (i.e. freeboard) E. Bridges conveying waterbodies that have controlled outlets or spillways require the following information:
  27. Elevations described in BDM Section 201.1.2.1.E.
  28. Size of drainage area
  29. Water body name 4. Owner of outlet or spillway
  30. Include a note indicating that the pool elevation is controlled by the outlet or spillway F. Buried culvert bridges with an invert: In addition to the information required in BDM Sections 201.1.2.2.D and E, provide the water pH and abrasion level (1-6). The required design service life is 75 years in accordance with L&D Volume 2, Section 1002.2.2. G. Proposed Structure block: Located in the lower right-hand corner of the sheet. The block shall be 6-1/2-in wide on a 22-in x 34-in sheet. The block shall include the following information:
  31. Type: provide a brief description of proposed bridge type
  32. Span(s): provide the span lengths and how measured (c/c of bearings, f/f of abutments) See BDM Section 201.1.2.1.H for additional information.
  33. Roadway: provide the roadway and sidewalk widths and how measured (t/t of bridge railing, t/t of curb, or f/f of railing)
  34. Vehicular Live Load: Provide the Vehicular Live Load designation used for the proposed design. If multiple Vehicular Live Load designations are applicable to the proposed structure, list all that apply. For each designation listed, provide the portion of the structure to which it applies. If necessary to conserve space on the Site Plan, place “See General Notes” in the Proposed Structure Block and provide the applicable designations there. BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-5
  35. Future Wearing Surface: Provide the Future Wearing Surface allowance (kip/ft2) used for proposed design If a future wearing surface is not included for the structure, then report the future wearing surface as zero.
  36. Skew: provide the skew angle and how measured (right forward or left forward)
  37. Approach Slabs: provide the length, thickness, and standard drawing number.
  38. Alignment: provide description of horizontal alignment across the bridge (e.g. tangent or degree of curvature and how measured)
  39. Crown or Superelevation: provide the rate of cross-slope
  40. Coordinates: provide the latitude and longitude for the proposed structure as defined in the Ohio Bridge Inventory Coding Guide and measured to the nearest 0.01 seconds.
  41. Deck Area as defined in the Ohio Bridge Inventory Coding Guide and taken to the nearest 1-ft2. H. Existing Structure block: Located in the lower right-hand corner of the sheet above the Proposed structure block. The block shall be 6-1/2-in wide on a 22-in x 34-in sheet. The block shall include the following information:
  42. Type: provide a brief description of existing bridge type
  43. Span(s): provide the span lengths and how measured (c/c of bearings, f/f of abutments)
  44. Roadway: provide the roadway width and how measured (t/t of bridge railing, t/t of curb, or f/f of railing)
  45. Vehicular Live Load: Provide the Vehicular Live Load designation used for the original design
  46. Skew: provide the skew angle and how measured (right forward or left forward)
  47. Wearing Surface: provide the type and thickness of the existing wearing surface
  48. Approach Slabs: provide known information regarding length, thickness, standard drawing number.
  49. Alignment: provide description of horizontal alignment across the bridge (e.g. tangent or degree of curvature and how measured)
  50. Crown or Superelevation: provide the rate of cross-slope
  51. Structure File Number: provide the SFN BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-6
  52. Date built: provide the year built and year of any major rehabilitations
  53. Disposition: provide the disposition of the existing bridge after the completion of the project I. A cross section of the proposed superstructure, including an elevation of the proposed pier type(s) if applicable. This may be shown on a separate sheet and should not be included in subsequent submittals on the site plan. J. The design and current average daily traffic (ADT) and the design average daily truck traffic (ADTT). Traffic data is available through the on-line resource: Traffic Monitoring Management System (TMMS). The traffic data provided on the Site Plan shall be reflective of the traffic on the bridge. For example, if the bridge carries one direction of a multi-lane divided highway, the traffic data shall be the directional portion of the total route traffic. Conversely, if the bridge carries two-way traffic, the traffic data shall be the total route traffic. There are many other possibilities, but regardless of the traffic pattern on the bridge, include a clear description of the traffic data provided on the Site Plan to avoid confusion. K. In the profile view, for each substructure unit where a bearing is to be used, designate the bearing condition as fixed (FIX), expansion (EXP) or integral (INT). Designate Semi-integral substructures as expansion (EXP) and integral as (INT). L. Navigational clearances M. A cross section sketch at the abutments to verify bridge limits. This may be shown on a separate sheet and should not be included in subsequent submittals on the site plan. 201.1.2.3 370BNARRATIVE OF BRIDGE ALTERNATIVES C201.1.2.3 Include a brief narrative in the Structure Type Study identifying the structure alternatives and their costs. If applicable, include information regarding the use of non-standard bridge railing. The purpose of the Narrative is to provide insight into why the particular proposed structure was chosen. Factors that need to be considered in selecting a structure for a particular site include geometry, economics, maintainability, constructability, right-of-way constraints, disruption to the traveling public, waterway crossing requirements or grade separations requirements, clearances for railway and highway crossings, foundation considerations, historical and environmental concerns, debris and ice flow problems and appearance. 201.1.2.4 371BCOST ANALYSIS C201.1.2.4 Include a cost analysis in the Structure Type Study comparing alternative structures. The cost analysis shall consider the initial construction cost and all major future rehabilitation and maintenance costs, converted to present dollars. Sufficient preliminary design is necessary for an accurate cost analysis. Construction cost data is available from the ODOT Office of Estimating. BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-7 201.1.2.5 372BFOUNDATION RECOMMENDATION C201.1.2.5 Include a written Foundation Recommendation in the Structure Type Study that consists of the following items: A. General foundation type (e.g. Drilled Shafts, Friction Piles, Bearing Piles or Spread Footings) B. Preliminary estimates of nominal and factored resistances: The primary purpose of the foundation recommendation is to identify the probable foundation type for the preferred structure alternative. Specific foundation information such as pile size, estimated pile length, ultimate bearing values, shaft diameter, rock socket dimensions and footing dimensions may be provided, but is not required at this stage. In addition to the above recommendations, include all pertinent geotechnical information gathered for the study area that forms the basis for the Foundation Recommendation. Performing drilling operations at this stage is not always necessary. Reasonable foundation assumptions for a Structure Type Study may be developed based on existing information gathered during the Office Reconnaissance detailed in the SGE. There may be project locations where sufficient geotechnical information is not available to render an accurate recommendation of foundation type or resistances. For such locations, boring, sampling and field testing according to the SGE will be necessary at this stage of the project development process When the foundation recommendation for the preferred alternative includes MSE wall supported abutments, provide estimates for factored bearing pressure and factored bearing resistance for the in-situ material below the MSE wall. Refer to BDM Section 201.4.1 for additional retaining wall design considerations. When considering retaining walls on a project, perform a Retaining Wall Justification, per ODOT L&D, Vol. 3, Section 1407.2, for all retaining walls other than abutments and culvert headwalls. Include an evaluation of feasible retaining wall types in the Retaining Wall Justification, including a comparison of the practicality, constructability and economics of each wall type. See BDM Section 307 for a description and design guidance for each wall type. 201.1.2.6 373BPRELIMINARY MAINTENANCE OF TRAFFIC PLAN C201.1.2.6 Include a Preliminary Maintenance of Traffic Plan in the Structure Type Study. The various stages of the bridge construction shall match those of the approach roadway, and the nomenclature used to identify the various stages (phases) of construction shall be the same for the roadway and the bridge (Stage 1 and Stage 2 or Phase 1 and Phase 2). This Plan shall include a transverse section(s) defining all stages of removal and construction with the following information: For projects that affect ODOT’s Permitted Lane Closure Schedule, evaluate Accelerated Bridge Construction (ABC) techniques to mitigate negative impacts to the travelling public. Access to the Permitted Lane Closure Schedule (maintained by the Office of Roadway Engineering) is available at: http://plcm.dot.state.oh.us/ Additional information regarding ABC techniques is available on FHWA’s Accelerated Bridge Construction Website: http://www.fhwa.dot.gov/bridge/abc/ BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-8 A. The existing superstructure and substructure layout with overall dimensions (field verified) and color photographs. B. Type of temporary railing or barrier. C. Proposed temporary lane widths, measured as the clear distance between temporary barriers. For information regarding temporary MOT geometrics refer to ODOT’s TEM, Section 640-2. D. Location of cut lines. Evaluate the existing structure to determine where the cut-line can be made to maintain structural integrity. Refer to BDM Section 404.5 for additional information on cutline locations for early concrete slab bridges. E. Temporary modifications to superelevated sections (existing and/or proposed) on the deck and/or shoulder in order to accommodate the traffic from the phase construction. F. Width of closure pour. Refer to BDM Section 309.3.8.5 for more information regarding closure pours. G. Profile grade, alignment, approximate location and width of temporary structures H. Location of temporary shoring I. Lane closure exceptions. Present alternative concepts when exceptions to the Department’s permitted lane closures are necessary. 201.2 53B RIDGE PRELIMINARY DESIGN REPORT – STAGE 1 201.2.1 170B RIDGE PRELIMINARY DESIGN REPORT SUBMISSION REQUIREMENTS C201.2.1 Provide a separate Bridge Preliminary Design Report for each SFN on a project. For identical parallel bridges that require separate SFN’s in accordance with the Ohio Bridge Inventory Coding Guide, develop a full Bridge Preliminary Design Report for one of the bridges. The Bridge Preliminary Design Report, for the twin structure shall refer to the full report to avoid duplication of effort. However, include a separate Final Structure Site Plan for each SFN. The Bridge Preliminary Design Report shall contain the following: This requirement shall also apply to bridges that do not require an SFN. At the approval of the Project Manager, an independent Bridge Preliminary Design Report may be provided for the twin structure. A. Final Structure Site Plan, see BDM Section 201.2.1.1 B. Final Maintenance of Traffic Plan, see BDM Section 201.2.1.2 C. Foundation Report, see BDM Section 201.2.1.3 D. Supplemental Site Plan for Railway Crossings, see BDM Section 201.2.1.4 E. Disposition of comments from the Structure Type Study BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-9 F. Non-standard bridge railing, see BDM Section 309.4.1 201.2.1.1 374BFINAL STRUCTURE SITE PLAN In addition to the Preliminary Structure Site Plan requirements of BDM Section 201.1.2.2, the Final Structure Site Plan shall include the information in the following sections. 201.2.1.1.a 510BPLAN VIEW C201.2.1.1.a The Final Structure Site Plan shall include the following information in the Plan View: Refer to BDM Section 201.1.2.2 for additional site plan view information. A. Bridge width and approach pavement widths, showing curb or bridge railing lines and outer limits of the superstructure and substructure units B. Skew angle of each substructure unit C. The directional bearing of the centerline of construction for tangent alignments or the directional bearing of the Reference Line for curved alignments. Provide a baseline/workline for structures located on a curve, spiral, or having other complex geometry in the plans along with enough information for the fabricator to meet the requirements of C&MS 513. C&MS 513 requires the fabricator to include in the Shop Drawings an overall layout with dimensions showing the horizontal position of beam or girder segments with respect to a full-length base or workline. Offsets from this full-length base line are to be provided by the fabricator for each 10-ft of length. D. Lateral clearances (both the minimum required and the actual) with respect to railroad tracks and/or highways under the proposed structure E. Location of minimum vertical clearance F. Treatment of slopes around the ends and under the bridge (location and length of rock channel protection) G. Channel changes H. Soil boring locations Use the soil boring symbols for Project Soil Borings and Historic Soil Borings at the correct scale in accordance with the ODOT CADD/ORD cell libraries and SGE Appendix D. Project Soil Borings are those drilled specifically for the design project; Historic Soil Borings are those drilled previously within the vicinity of the proposed structure. Provide a Legend adjacent to the Plan View with the same soil boring symbols. Provide the descriptions "Project Boring Location" for Project Soil Borings and "Historic Boring Location" for Historic Soil Borings. I. Centerline of temporary structure and temporary approach pavement BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-10 J. Stationing of Bridge Limits K. Limits of channel excavation shown by crosshatching with a description provided in a legend L. The location and description of benchmarks M. The following earthwork note: EARTHWORK limits shown are approximate. Actual slopes shall conform to plan cross sections. N. Guardrail stationing When providing guardrail stationing: for bridges with twin steel tube bridge railing, station the centerline of the first top mounted post on the bridge, for bridges with deep beam railing and concrete bridge railing, station the centerline of the first guardrail post off the bridge. Stationing shall be given to the nearest 1/100th of a foot. Guardrail stationing is subject to change during the detail design phase. The Site Plan shall be revised accordingly. This information coincides with the Method of Measurement defined in C&MS Item 517. These stations are used to determine pay length of roadway approach guardrail which is typically given in multiples of standard w-beam lengths. 201.2.1.1.b 511BPROFILE VIEW C201.2.1.1.b The Final Structure Site Plan shall include the following information in the Profile view: Refer to BDM Section 201.1.2.2 for additional site plan profile view information. A. Profile gradient percent B. Embankment slopes and top of slope elevations C. Proposed bottom of footing elevations D. Type of foundations E. Top of bedrock elevations at each boring location (if encountered in the boring). Show the top of bedrock elevation with line style "ground" from ODOT CADD Engineering Standards Manual, Appendix D, or provide a table of values.) F. Shaded areas of the bridge that represent the new bridge components. 201.2.1.1.c 512BSUPERELEVATION TRANSITION Provide a superelevation transition table or diagram similar to BDM Figure 309-11, if the bridge crown changes across the structure. When detailing the typical bridge transverse section, provide a reference to the table or diagram. 201.2.1.2 375BFINAL MAINTENANCE OF TRAFFIC PLAN In addition to the Preliminary Maintenance of Traffic Plan requirements of BDM Section 201.1.2.6, the Final Maintenance of Traffic Plan shall include the following information: A. Plan view BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-11 B. Temporary barrier anchorage details and requirements C. Location and type of temporary shoring (See BDM Section 310.1) D. Location of structural members that require strengthening E. Temporary structure design information (See BDM Section 500) F. Additional notes and/or details that will be necessary to perform the work 201.2.1.3 376BSTRUCTURE FOUNDATION EXPLORATION REPORT C201.2.1.3 Include a Structure Foundation Exploration Report in accordance with the SGE in the Bridge Preliminary Design Report. The Structure Foundation Exploration Report shall include: Specific design considerations for each foundation type are presented in BDM Section 305. A. Summary of Exploration B. Investigational Findings C. Analyses and Recommendations D. Boring Logs E. Test Data For the scour evaluation, performed in accordance with the L&D, Vol. 2, provide: A. For granular (cohesionless) soils, D50 values from the particle size analysis B. For cohesive soils, a classification package in accordance with SGE Table 600-19 (includes Visual Description, Water Content Determination, Particle-Size Analysis, Hydrometer, Liquid Limit, Plastic Limit, and Plasticity Index), and a measurement of unconfined compressive strength C. For bedrock, the unconfined compressive strength (Qu), Slake Durability Index (SDI), Rock Quality Designation (RQD), total unit weight, Rock Mass Rating (RMR) or Geologic Strength Index (GSI), and an evaluation of bedrock structure in accordance with BDM Section 305.2.1.2.b.B. Where the scour evaluation has identified a potential problem, accommodate the probable scour depths, calculated in accordance with L&D, Vol. 2, for: the design of the substructures; the location of the bottom of footings; the minimum tip elevations for piles and drilled shafts; and the factored side resistance of piles and drilled shafts. BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-12 Where downdrag has been identified as a potential contributor to the total factored load, include the estimated downdrag load in the report. See BDM Section 305.3.2.2 for more information regarding downdrag. 201.2.1.3.a 513BSPREAD FOOTING REPORT REQUIREMENTS For spread footings, provide the size of the footing, external stability analyses, predicted settlement, eccentric load limitations, factored sliding resistance, Service I Limit State bearing pressure, maximum Strength Limit State bearing pressure, and the factored bearing resistance; provide all supporting calculations for these values. Also provide all relevant plan notes for the footing installation including necessary waiting periods. 201.2.1.3.b 514BPILE FOUNDATION REPORT REQUIREMENTS C201.2.1.3.b For driven pile foundations, provide the size and type of driven piles analyzed, the estimated and order length per pile, the nominal and factored loads per pile, the nominal and factored geotechnical and structural resistance per pile, predicted settlement (magnitude and time-rate), horizontal deflections, the pile driving hammer rated energy used for wave equation drivability analyses, and the maximum driving stresses resulting from the drivability analyses. For the geotechnical resistance, provide the following: A. Nominal unit tip resistance, qp (ksf) B. Nominal unit side resistance, qs for each soil layer contributing to the nominal pile side resistance (ksf) C. Design methodologies used to determine unit tip and unit side resistances Provide supporting calculations for all of the above. Also provide all relevant plan notes for the pile installation including necessary waiting periods. For friction piles, the nominal axial geotechnical resistance is referred to as Ultimate Bearing Value (UBV). 201.2.1.3.c 515BDRILLED SHAFT FOUNDATION REPORT REQUIREMENTS For drilled shaft foundations, provide the nominal dimensions and the size and type of reinforcement for the drilled shafts analyzed, the nominal and factored loads per shaft, the nominal and factored geotechnical and structural resistance per shaft, predicted settlement (magnitude and time-rate), and horizontal deflections. For the geotechnical resistance, provide the following: A. Nominal unit tip resistance, qp (ksf) B. Nominal unit side resistance, qs for each soil layer contributing to the nominal shaft side resistance (ksf) BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-13 C. Design methodologies used to determine unit tip and unit side resistances D. Resistance factor from BDM Table 305-1 for each calculated unit resistance. E. Integrity testing methods (if applicable). Provide a justification when specifying drilled shaft integrity testing methods other than Thermal Integrity Profiling (TIP), such as Gamma-Gamma Logging (GGL) or Pile Integrity Testing (PIT), or if specifying Crosshole Sonic Logging (CSL) testing for drilled shafts of less than 84-in nominal diameter. Provide supporting calculations for all the above. Also provide all relevant plan notes for the drilled shaft installation. 201.2.1.3.d 516BMICROPILES FOUNDATION REPORT REQUIREMENTS For micropile foundations, provide for review the nominal dimensions and the size and type of reinforcement for the micropiles analyzed, the nominal and factored loads per pile, the nominal and factored geotechnical and structural resistance per pile, predicted settlement (magnitude and time-rate), and horizontal deflections. For the geotechnical resistance, provide the following: A. Nominal unit tip resistance, qp (ksf) B. Nominal unit side resistance, qs for each soil layer contributing to the nominal pile side resistance (ksf) C. Design methodologies used to determine unit tip and unit side resistances D. Resistance factor from BDM Table 305-1 for each calculated unit resistance. Provide supporting calculations for all of the above. Also provide all relevant plan notes for the micropile foundation installation. 201.2.1.3.e 517BCONTINUOUS FLIGHT AUGER (CFA) PILE FOUNDATIONS REPORT REQUIREMENTS For Continuous Flight Auger pile foundations, provide for review the nominal dimensions and the size and type of reinforcement for the CFA piles analyzed, the nominal and factored loads per pile, the nominal and factored geotechnical and structural resistance per pile, predicted settlement (magnitude and time-rate), and horizontal deflections. For the geotechnical resistance, provide the following: A. Nominal unit tip resistance, qp (ksf) BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-14 B. Nominal unit side resistance, qs for each soil layer contributing to the nominal pile side resistance (ksf) C. Design methodologies used to determine unit tip and unit side resistances D. Resistance factor from BDM Table 305-1 for each calculated unit resistance. Provide supporting calculations for all of the above. Also provide all relevant plan notes for the CFA pile installation. 201.2.1.3.f 518BMSE WALL REPORT REQUIREMENTS For MSE wall supported abutments provide findings for external stability (LRFD 11.10.5) and settlement. Also provide soil reinforcement lengths, and all construction constraints, such as soil improvement methods, that will be required. Provide supporting calculations for all of the above. Also provide all relevant plan notes for the MSE wall installation. 201.2.1.4 377BSUPPLEMENTAL SITE PLAN FOR RAILWAY CROSSINGS C201.2.1.4 For Railway-Highway grade separation structures, provide a Supplemental Site Plan with the Final Site Plan. Show the following information in the Supplemental Site Plan: The railway traffic counts have been removed to avoid duplication and possible conflicts as these are provided in the railroad agreements A. A 1-in = 100-ft scale plan of the alignment of the railroad and the highway extended at least 1000-ft each way from the proposed point of intersection, taken from actual surveys. B. Profile of top of all rails, extending at least 1000-ft each way from the proposed intersection. C. Minimum lateral and vertical clearances to all tracks. D. Sufficient cross sections along the railroad and highway to determine approximate earthwork limits and encroachment on railroad property. E. Drainage. F. Intersection angle between highway centerline and railroad centerline. G. Highway stationing and railroad mile post stationing at intersection. H. Railroad right-of-way lines. BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-15 I. Railroad pole lines, signal control boxes, communications relay houses, signal standards and drainage structures. J. Centerlines of all tracks and location of switch points. K. Location of buildings or other structures within the railroad right-of-way. L. Location of all utilities occupying railroad right-of-way and the names of the owners of these utilities. 201.3 54BWATERWAY PERMIT DETERMINATION 201.3.1 171B RIDGE AND WATERWAY PERMITS C201.3.1 Impacts to bridges or waterways may require legal authorization in the form of permits or certifications issued by various regulatory agencies, including: A1. U.S. Army Corps of Engineers – Section 404, Section 408 and/or Section 10 Permit B1. U.S. Coast Guard – Section 9 Bridge Permit C1. Ohio EPA – Section 401 Water Quality Certification and/or Isolated Wetland Permit The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) has jurisdiction over “Waters of the United States” and, as noted in ODOT C&MS 101.03, this includes: rivers, streams, jurisdictional ditches, lakes and wetlands. For rivers, streams and jurisdictional ditches, the jurisdiction begins at the OHWM. The OHWM is defined by the USACE Regulatory Letter No. 05-05 and is available at the following website: https://usace.contentdm.oclc.org/utils/getfile/collectio n/p16021coll9/id/1253 Coordinate with the DEC and the OES-WPU throughout the waterway permit process to ensure that the final waterway permit applications are indicative of the final project design. For more information refer to the Waterway Permits Manual available on the ODOT Office of Environmental Services website. The ODOT Office of Environmental Services – Waterway Permits Unit (OES-WPU) assumes the responsibility for determining which types of waterway permits apply to ODOT projects, such as, but not limited to, Nationwide Permits (NWP) or ODOT’s Regional General Permit (RGP). Confirm with the project manager that the bridge design plans meet the requirements in the project waterway Special Provisions (SP) and ensure the project waterway SP is submitted with the Final Plan Package. Special Provisions are the method ODOT uses to attach the waterway permit conditions to the project construction plans. The waterway permits Special Provisions is prepared by the OES-WPU and may contain the following: A2. All pertinent waterway permit conditions B2. Plan sheets and mapping approved by the regulatory agencies. BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-16 C2. Impact quantities authorized in aquatic resources. D2. Section 404 Completion Certification form 201.3.2 172BTEMPORARY ACCESS FILLS C201.3.2 A Temporary Access Fill (TAF) is a fill or structure that allows a contractor access to work on roads or bridges located within bodies of water. Examples of TAF’s include cofferdams; temporary structures for maintaining traffic; causeways and workpads; and demolition debris. The placement of all TAF’s in “Waters of the United States” must be performed in accordance with the special provisions for waterway permits. A contractor’s means and methods of construction will dictate the TAF required for a project. However, the Department must estimate the potential impacts to “Waters of the United States” during project development to enable all permits to be in-place during contract letting. For most projects, the waterway permits are in place prior to sale. There may be instances where unforeseen delays dictate that the waterway permits will not be acquired until after sale and/or award; however, the Department will still provide Waterway Permit Special Provisions prior to project sale indicating anticipated conditions and the pending permit authorizations. In those instances, it is imperative that the waterway permits be obtained prior to the contractor beginning any work within any Waters of the United States. Furthermore, it is incumbent upon the Department that these permits provide all bidding contractors the ability to construct the project without resulting in expensive delays, change orders or fines. Use the following requirements to estimate the size of TAF’s: A. The TAF shall provide access to all piers located within the OHWM of the waterway from at least one bank of the waterway. The Department partnered with the Ohio Contractor’s Association to develop these requirements. This information is intended for permit application purposes only and should not be included in the project plan set. However, to assist the OES-WPU in the determination process, Designers should calculate worst case scenario TAF impacts, including linear footage from upstream to downstream and acreage, to submit in the Permit Determination Request to OES. An example Plan, Profile and Cross-section using the guidance provided above are shown in BDM Figure 201-1. These quantities should be provided to the DEC along with a completed copy of the checklist shown on the OES Waterway Permit Determination Request website. The minimum flow to be maintained during construction should be calculated according to BDM Section 201.3.2.F. Designers will need to estimate whether this flow can be maintained through conduits or if open channels will be required. BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-17 In the case of staging, the permit application shall reflect the construction stage that impacts the largest area of the waterway. Access may be provided by construction staging of the TAF. When considering the constructability of staged TAF’s, typical superstructure erection plans for lifting lengths of 50-ft or more require two cranes. Unless the access for member delivery is from an adjacent structure, the TAF must provide access to each end of the lift from one bank. B. Locate the TAF directly beneath the superstructure. The surface width of the TAF shall be equal to the out-to-out width of the superstructure plus 50-ft outboard on one side of the structure and 20-ft outboard on the other side of the structure. C. Extend the TAF at least 40-ft beyond the furthest pier accessed by the TAF. D. The side slopes of the TAF shall be no steeper than 1.5:1 (H:V). E. Locate the top surface of the TAF at least 1-ft above the OHWM. F. Design the TAF to maintain the Standard Temporary Discharge (STD) as detailed in L&D, Vol. 2, Section 1012. BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-18 Figure 201-1 BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-19 201.4 55BDETAIL DESIGN – STAGE 2 C201.4 Provide a separate plan set for each SFN on a project. The Stage 2 structure submission for bridges, retaining walls and noise walls shall include a disposition of the comments from the previous submission and the items listed below. Not every item listed will apply to every project. Upon approval of the bridge Owner and Project Manager, plan notes and details for bridge rehabilitation and maintenance work items on multiple bridges may be combined into one plan set with estimated quantities for each bridge shown in the General Summary. A. Include the following in the Bridge Plans: 1. Site Plan in compliance with all Stage 1 review comments
  54. General Plan (if required) 3. General Notes Bridge plans at this stage are essentially complete except for Estimated Quantity values and Concrete Reinforcement Bar Lists. To avoid the potential of wasted effort, completion of these two plan items which are subject to change based on the Stage 2 Plan Review is deferred to Stage 3.
  55. Estimated Quantities showing all pay items and item extensions. Quantity values are not required at this stage.
  56. Phase Construction Details (if required)
  57. Foundation Plan (if required) 7. Abutment Details with all dimensioning, bar sizes, bar shapes and bar spacings properly shown
  58. Pier Details with all dimensioning, bar sizes, bars shapes and bar spacings properly shown (if required)
  59. Superstructure Details with all dimensioning, bar sizes, bar shapes and bar spacings properly shown
  60. Approach Slab Details with all dimensioning, bar sizes, bar shapes and bar spacings properly shown (if necessary)
  61. Concrete Reinforcement Bar Lists. Bar marks, dimensions, quantities and weights are not required at this stage.
  62. Other Details as necessary B. Include the following in the Retaining Wall Plans:
  63. General Notes
  64. Retaining wall details
  65. Other Details as necessary C. Noise Barrier Plans in accordance with BDM Section 800. D. Special Provisions E. Load Rating Reports for bridges F. Signed Office of Structural Engineering Bridge Stage 2 Plan Review Checklist Refer to BDM Section 900 for the Load Rating Report submission requirements at this stage. BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-20 201.4.1 173BRETAINING WALLS C201.4.1 Provide a complete design for each retaining wall in accordance with BDM Section 307. The design shall include external stability analysis for the foundations of retaining walls in accordance with BDM Section 305.1. If specifying a proprietary (prefabricated) retaining wall, provide sufficient information in the plans such that, prior to submitting a bid, the Contractor can select a proprietary company to design the internal stability of the prefabricated retaining wall after the project is awarded. Detail each wall on a project separately. For MSE wall examples, see BDM Figure 201-2, Figure 201-3, Figure 201-4, Figure 201-5, Figure 201-6, and Figure 201-7. As a minimum, provide the following information in the project plans for each wall location: A. Plan View of the wall showing: 1. A wall baseline along the front (exposed) face of the wall 2. For each critical point: station and offset with respect to the centerline of construction
  66. All complex geometry information 4. Pay limits for wall and roadway quantities
  67. North Arrow 6. Locations of typical sections for (C.) below 7. Locations of abutment footing, piles, utilities, catch basins, and other possible obstructions (Refer to BDM Section 309.7 for drainage and BDM Section 310.4.1 for utility locations)
  68. Concrete bridge railing/barrier locations
  69. Limits of proposed wall excavation 10. Locations of sheeting and bracing If sheeting and bracing is required according to BDM Section 310.1, provide a pay item for ITEM 503 – COFFERDAMS AND EXCAVATION BRACING
  70. Locations of call drainage BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-21 Locate perforated plastic pipe, C&MS 707.33, wrapped with geotextile fabric as low as possible behind the wall while still providing positive gravity flow in the pipe to an outlet. Locate pipe as near as possible the back side of the leveling pad and near the free end of the soil reinforcement. The pipe shall be continuous and sloped to provide a positive gravity flow to an outlet. Show the approximate location of the outlet on the plan view. Use drainage pipe without perforations outside the wall. See BDM Section 307 for additional guidance on drainage for various wall types. If the wall supports an abutment, provide backfill drainage in accordance with BDM Section 306.2.3.1. B. Elevation of the wall showing: 1. Station and elevation for each critical point on the wall
  71. Finished ground surface elevations for each critical point on the wall
  72. Footing or leveling pad showing the minimum dimension from the finished ground line to the top of the footing or pad. If the wall has no footing (e.g. a drilled shaft wall or soil nail wall) show the dimensions of any deep foundation elements and the dimension from the finished ground line to the foundation elevation (or top of deep foundation elements).
  73. Locations of abutment footing, piles, utilities, catch basins, and other possible obstructions
  74. Backfill drainage
  75. Approximate locations of slip joints, if applicable C. Typical Sections showing:
  76. Coping details, if applicable 2. Concrete bridge railing and sleeper slab details 3. Abutment footing details including the dimensions from the back of the wall stem or face to the centerline of bearing at the abutment, dimensions from the back of the wall stem or face to the toe of the abutment footing, and dimensions from the back of the wall stem or face to the centerline of the nearest row of piles.
  77. For MSE walls, minimum clearance between the bottom of the footing/sleeper slab and the uppermost wall reinforcement strap. The preferred dimension is 6-in. BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-22
  78. Locations of abutment footings, piles, utilities, catch basins, and other possible obstructions
  79. Backfill drainage
  80. For MSE walls, soil reinforcements attached to abutments. Regardless of abutment type and foundation type, one row of soil reinforcements shall be attached to the backside of the abutment footing. These additional reinforcements are necessary to resist horizontal bridge and backwall forces and prevent load transfer to the coping and facing panels. To estimate select granular backfill quantities, Designers may assume these additional reinforcements are the same length as those attached to the facing panels.
  81. For MSE walls, limits of select granular material. The top elevation of the select granular backfill shall be at least 6-in above the uppermost layer of soil reinforcement, but not lower than 6-in above the bottom of the abutment footing.
  82. Limits of wall excavation For MSE walls, SS840 requires a minimum 1- ft undercut beneath the leveling pad elevation. If more undercut is required, show it on the plans. The backfill material is specified in SS840. For prefabricated modular retaining walls, SS870 requires a minimum 1-ft undercut beneath the wall modules or concrete leveling pad elevation. If more undercut is required, show it on the plans. The backfill material is specified in SS870.
  83. Pay limits of wall and roadway quantities 11. Pile sleeves (if required) Show pile sleeves extending from the bottom of the abutment footing to the bottom of the wall excavation.
  84. Location of sheeting and bracing (if required)
  85. Limits of concrete sealer D. Requirements for wall surface textures or other aesthetic treatments. For prefabricated retaining walls, provide the panel or module size and shape restrictions specific to the project in the plans. E. Wall design criteria including:
  86. Factored bearing resistance at the base of the footing or reinforced soil mass, or at the foundation elevation for other types of walls and wall foundations. BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-23
  87. The following factored loads applied to the wall or reinforced soil mass from the bridge: vertical dead and live loads, horizontal loads, and total bearing load. Plan notes for MSE walls are provided in BDM Section 605.5. Plan notes for spread footings (for the wall types in BDM Section 307.2) are provided in BDM Section 606.6. F. Final copy of the Special Provisions for proprietary wall types, if applicable. G. Estimated Quantities Table (list each wall on a project separately) For proprietary wall types, include all necessary pay items listed in the applicable Special Provisions: SS840 for MSE walls; SS851 for precast gravity and semigravity retaining walls, SS867 for wire faced MSE walls; SS870 for prefabricated modular retaining walls. Also include the following pay items as necessary: ITEM 203 EMBANKMENT; ITEM 203 GRANULAR EMBANKMENT; ITEM 503 UNCLASSIFIED EXCAVATION; ITEM 503 COFFERDAMS AND EXCAVATION BRACING; ITEM 509 EPOXY COATED REINFORCING STEEL; ITEM 511 CLASS QC1 CONCRETE WITH QC/QA, FOOTING; ITEM 512 SEALING OF CONCRETE SURFACES (EPOXY URETHANE); ITEM 518 PREFABRICATED GEOCOMPOSITE DRAIN; ITEM 518 CORRUGATED POLYETHYLENE SMOOTH LINED PIPE. BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-24 Figure 201-2 BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-25 Figure 201-3 BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-26 Figure 201-4 BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-27 Figure 201-5 BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-28 Figure 201-6 BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-29 Figure 201-7 BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-30 201.5 56BDETAIL DESIGN – STAGE 3 C201.5 Provide a separate plan set for each SFN on a project. The Stage 3 structure submission for bridges and retaining walls shall include final plans, a disposition of Stage 2 comments and a signed Office of Structural Engineering Bridge Stage 3 Checklist. Estimated Quantities and Concrete Reinforcement Bar Lists shall be complete at this stage. Submit Load Rating Reports for qualifying bridge and project types according to BDM Section 900. Resolve all Stage 2 comments to the satisfaction of the owner. Upon approval of the bridge Owner and Project Manager, plan notes and details for bridge rehabilitation and maintenance work items on multiple bridges may be combined into one plan set with estimated quantities for each bridge shown in the General Summary. 201.6 57BFINAL TRACINGS C201.6 Provide a separate plan set for each SFN on a project. The structural submission for final tracings shall include the final bridge plans and any special provisions along with a copy of the Estimated Quantity calculations in accordance with BDM Section 102.5 and LD-4 Estimating Information form in accordance with the L&D, Vol. 3. Upon approval of the bridge Owner and Project Manager, plan notes and details for bridge rehabilitation and maintenance work items on multiple bridges may be combined into one plan set with estimated quantities for each bridge shown in the General Summary. 202 5BLIMITED REVIEW PROCESS C202 Do not utilize the Limited Review Process defined in L&D, Vol. 3 Section 1404.2, for projects involving work on bridges. This process does not require ODOT reviews for design activities associated with Stage 1, Stage 2 or Stage 3. As noted in BDM Section 104, structure reviews shall not be omitted from the Project Development Process. If the Project Manager and bridge Owner determine that without staged review oversight the proposed bridge work poses no safety risk and minimal risk for construction cost overruns, then the Limited Review Process may be utilized. 203 6BDESIGN-BUILD REVIEW PROCESS C203 Refer to the Scope of Services for the project’s structure review submission requirements. Depending upon the size and scope of a project, structure submissions may be required at Stage 1 only; Stage 1, Stage 2 and Stage 3; or any combination in between sometimes expressed as a completion percentage of the entire design effort (e.g. 50% completion, 90% completion, etc.). These staged submissions may also be provided in buildable units (e.g. foundations, Rear Abutment, Pier 1, Superstructure Unit 1, etc.) rather than complete structures. BDM Section 200 – General Information 2020 Edition – January 2025 2-31 204 7BLOCAL-LET LOCAL PUBLIC AGENCY (LPA) PROJECT REVIEW PROCESS C204 A Stage 2 review submission is required for all Local-Let LPA projects. The District LPA Manager will determine if additional review submissions are required for more complex projects. Local-let LPA projects are those in which the LPA assumes project administration duties. For more information, refer to L&D, Vol. 3 Section 1404.4 and the ODOT Locally Administered Transportation Projects Manual of Procedures. Structure Type Study, Bridge Preliminary Design Report, Stage 1 and Stage 3 review submissions should be considered for the following project types: new bridge, bridge replacement, superstructure replacement, superstructure rehabilitation, superstructure widening, deck replacement, new retaining wall and retaining wall rehabilitation. All Local-Let LPA required Stage submissions shall be in accordance with BDM Section 201.
