Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-1 SECTION 300 – DETAIL DESIGN 301 8BDESIGN SPECIFICATIONS C301 Develop Ohio Department of Transportation bridge designs in conformance with the latest edition of the American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials (AASHTO) LRFD Bridge Design Specifications. Refer to BDM Section 101.1 for additional contract document requirements ODOT’s supplement to the AASHTO LRFD specifications are documented in BDM Section 1000. 302 9B RIDGE GEOMETRICS 302.1 58BVERTICAL CLEARANCE C302.1 Show the “Required Minimum” and “Actual Minimum” Vertical Clearances and their locations on the Preliminary Structure Site Plan, BDM Section 201.1.2.2 For grade separation structures over a roadway, the “Required Minimum” Vertical Clearance shall not be less than specified in L&D, Vol. 1, Section 302 unless otherwise specified in the Scope of Services. Prepare a Design Exception in accordance with Section 105 of the L&D, Vol. 1 when the “Actual Minimum” Vertical Clearance is less than the L&D Manual minimum clearance. The “Actual Minimum” Vertical Clearance is the theoretical overhead clearance provided by the design plans. 302.2 59B RIDGE WIDTH Establish bridge superstructure widths in accordance with L&D, Vol. 1, Section 302, unless specified in the Scope of Services. 302.3 60BLATERAL CLEARANCE C302.3 Provide divided highways having four or more lanes crossing under an intersecting highway with a minimum lateral clearance of 30-ft from the edge of traveled lane to the nearest obstruction. Establish lateral clearances for other roadway classifications in accordance with L&D, Vol. 1, unless specified in the Scope of Services. An obstruction would be a traffic barrier, wall, column or a non-traversable slope. For a non-traversable 2:1 slope, measure the lateral clearance to the point where the 2:1 back slope intersects the radius at the toe of the 2:1 slope. Refer to L&D, Vol. 1, Figure 307-2E for an illustration of safety grading for ditch sections. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-2 302.4 61BINTERFERENCE DUE TO EXISTING SUBSTRUCTURE C302.4 Do not locate a new substructure unit where an existing substructure or its foundation would interfere with the foundation or construction of the proposed substructure unit. This applies particularly where piles are to be driven. It is desirable to avoid the difficulty and expense of removing deep underground portions of the existing substructure and to avoid the resultant disturbance of the ground. Obstructions within the footprint of the new substructure shall be completely removed to avoid interference. Where existing substructure units are shown on the Site Plan, place the locations precisely. Show the existing substructure configuration based on existing plans or field verified dimensions. Misrepresentation of the location of the existing substructure units has resulted in expensive change orders during construction. Label existing dimensions as (+/-) plus or minus in the contract documents. 302.5 62B RIDGE STRUCTURE, SKEW, CURVATURE AND SUPERELEVATION C302.5 During preliminary engineering, investigate alternatives that eliminate the presence of skew angles that exceed 30°, horizontal curves and superelevation transitions within the actual bridge limits. Skews, curves and superelevation transitions add complexity which can increase costs and also result in poor ride quality. 303 10BDESIGN LOADING 303.1 63BHIGHWAY BRIDGES 303.1.1 174BVEHICULAR LIVE LOAD Design all bridges that carry highway traffic for an HL-93 loading as specified in LRFD 3.6.1.2.1. 303.1.2 175BFUTURE WEARING SURFACE Design all bridges that carry highway traffic for a future wearing surface (FWS) of 0.060-ksf except as noted in BDM Section 401.3 303.1.3 176BLONGITUDINAL FORCES C303.1.3 Assume force effects transferred through bearings to the substructure occur at the bearing seat elevation. Bearings that permit rotation (e.g. elastomeric bearings, rocker bearings, etc.) will develop eccentricities resulting in applied moments as defined in LRFD 14.6.3.2. Typically, these eccentricities are negligible with respect to the design of the substructures that support the bearings and may be ignored. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-3 The total factored longitudinal loading applied to the substructure at each expansion bearing shall be the larger of: A. The Frictional Force acting on the substructure if the bearing slides. B. The bearing’s nominal (i.e. unfactored) resistance to longitudinal loading. A properly designed expansion bearing will utilize friction in lieu of mechanical anchorage to prevent the bearing from sliding under lateral loading. For these bearings, the maximum lateral loading on the substructure unit will be in the form of Friction, LRFD 3.13. For bearings that require mechanical anchorage, the bearing’s resistance to lateral loading represents the maximum lateral load on the substructure unit. Resistance in this instance is nominal because it is applied to the substructure as a loading. 303.1.4 177BSEISMIC C303.1.4 All bridges in the State of Ohio are located within Seismic Performance Zone 1. Refer to BDM Section 305.1.5 for Seismic Geotechnical requirements. This provision is based on Ohio’s seismologic data which is explained in BDM Section 305.1.5. 303.1.4.1 378BSEISMIC PERFORMANCE ZONE 1 C303.1.4.1 Seismic analysis is not required except as noted in BDM Sections 303.1.4.1.a and 303.1.4.1.b. Bridges designed according to the Strength and Service Limit States of the AASHTO LRFD Bridge Design Specifications are assumed to have sufficient capacity to resist Seismic Performance Zone 1 design loads applied at the Extreme Limit State. For bridges founded at locations with 0.10 ≤ SD1 < 0.15, specify transverse reinforcement at the top and bottom of columns in accordance with LRFD 5.11.4.1.4 and 5.11.4.1.5. BDM Figure 303-1 provides sample details for a cap and column pier that conform to the requirements of LRFD 5.11.4.1.4 and 5.11.4.1.5. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-4 Figure 303-1 303.1.4.1.a 519BMINIMUM SUPPORT LENGTH REQUIREMENTS C303.1.4.1.a Size the bearing supports according to LRFD 4.7.4.4. This provision exists to prevent the partial or complete collapse of the superstructure during seismic events. As a minimum, the overlapping distance of the superstructure and substructure bearing areas shall meet 100% of the minimal support length, N, calculated according to LRFD EQ. 4.7.4.4-1. Measure the minimum support lengths normal to the centerline of supports. Account for any expansion/contraction movements of the bearings when establishing final seat widths. Refer to BDM Figure 303-2 for the application of support length requirements to a typical expansion elastomeric bearing at an abutment. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-5 Figure 303-2 BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-6 303.1.4.1.b 520BHORIZONTAL CONNECTION FORCE C303.1.4.1.b All structures shall have some mechanism to transfer horizontally applied superstructure loads (e.g. vehicular braking force, centrifugal force, vehicular collision force, friction load, water load, wind load, and wind load on live load) to the substructure to ensure structural stability. During a seismic event, design these mechanisms, that prevent the free horizontal translation of the superstructure in any direction relative to the substructure, to transfer an applied horizontal connection force at the Extreme Event I Limit State. Only provide additional restraint for seismic loads (e.g. seismic pedestals) where the mechanisms noted above do not provide sufficient capacity. Refer to BDM Section 303.1.4.1.c for bearing requirements. Examples of mechanisms include fixed bearings, bearing guides, abutment diaphragms, diaphragm guides, wing walls and wind locks. The magnitude of the connection force shall be 0.15 or 0.25 times the tributary permanent load at the location of the restraint as determined in LRFD 3.10.9.2. If sufficient geotechnical information is not available to determine Site Class, assume the magnitude of the connection force is 0.25 times the tributary permanent load. The load factor for live load, γEQ, may be taken as 0.0. The tributary permanent load defined in LRFD 3.10.9.2 represents the factored dead load of the superstructure applying load to the device or object providing the directional restraint. If every bearing supporting the superstructure provides transverse restraint, the tributary permanent load applied to each restraint would equal the factored dead load reaction at each bearing. If only one transverse restraint was provided at each substructure unit, the tributary permanent load applied to each restraint would equal the sum of the factored dead load reactions for each bearing at the substructure unit. If only one transverse restraint was provided for the entire superstructure unit, the tributary permanent load applied to the restraint would equal the sum of the factored dead load reactions of every bearing. Longitudinal restraint connection forces would be determined similarly. For restraint provided in multiple directions, LRFD 3.10.8 applies. Because a structure in Seismic Performance Zone 1 is assumed to be able to carry the loads within the elastic strength range of its members or is assumed to be properly detailed to prevent collapse beyond the elastic strength range of its members, analysis of the superstructure, substructure and foundation for the load effects resulting from the connection force is not required. Provide cross-frames, designed to resist Strength and Service load combinations, to create a direct load path from the point of horizontal connection force application to the deck. These cross-frame do not need to be designed for Extreme Event limit state loading. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-7 303.1.4.1.c 521BREQUIREMENTS FOR BEARINGS The Department will permit unrestrained bearings that sustain irreparable damage during a seismic event provided loss of span is prevented by the design for the Horizontal Connection Force in BDM Section 303.1.4.1.b. 303.1.4.2 379BEXISTING STRUCTURES Evaluate the seismic vulnerability of an existing structure for rehabilitation projects requiring complete deck or superstructure replacements. Design new substructure units in accordance with LRFD 3.10.9.2, 4.7.4.4 and BDM Section 303.1.4.2.b. If sufficient geotechnical information is not available, assume: A. AS > 0.05 B. SD1 < 0.10 303.1.4.2.a 522BSUPERSTRUCTURE For projects where seismic vulnerability is evaluated, at bearing locations that will transmit the horizontal connection force from the substructure to the superstructure, provide cross-frames to resist Strength and Service load combinations to create a direct load path to the deck. For supports not in compliance with LRFD 4.7.4.4, provide seismic restrainers designed for the Horizontal Connection Force, specified in BDM Section 303.1.4.1.b. 303.1.4.2.b 523BSUBSTRUCTURE C303.1.4.2.b For projects where seismic vulnerability is considered, concrete columns at piers that transfer the seismic horizontal connection force, according to BDM Section 303.1.4.1.b, shall meet the spiral and tie ductility requirements of LRFD Eq. 5.11.4.1.4-1 and LRFD 5.10.4. Do not use LRFD Eq. 5.6.4.6-1. Designers may consider releasing restraint provided by existing pier bearings as a viable seismic retrofit provided the abutments can accommodate the additional horizontal Strength and Service loadings. Otherwise, provide the required confinement of the primary steel in the axially loaded substructure members. LRFD Eq. 5.6.4.6-1 provides erroneous results based on the ratio of Ag/Ac. As the concrete cover increases, impractical areas of transverse reinforcement are required. LRFD Eq. 5.11.4.1.4-1 provides the volumetric reinforcement requirements for confinement of primary steel at locations where plastic hinges are formed during seismic events. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-8 One acceptable method to increase the amount of confinement provided in an existing concrete column is through the use of Fiber Reinforced Polymer (FRP) wrap systems. For bridges located in regions with an acceleration coefficient, SD1 < 0.10, specify a confining stress due to FRP jacket (f1) of 0.150-ksi for the entire height of the column from the top of the footing/drilled shaft to the bottom of the cap. For bridges located in regions with an acceleration coefficient, SD1 ≥ 0.10, specify a confining stress due to FRP jacket (f1) of 0.300-ksi in the plastic hinge regions as defined in LRFD 5.11.4.1.5 and 0.150-ksi in the remaining portions of the columns. The plans shall include an elevation view of the columns with these confining stress regions clearly defined. These systems are a viable alternative for dry columns supported on pile caps, spread footings and drilled shafts. Research has shown that providing a confining stress of 0.300-ksi in regions where plastic hinges may form at the top and bottom of columns as defined in LRFD 5.11.4.1.5 and providing a confining stress of 0.150-ksi outside of the plastic hinge regions is sufficient to prevent buckling of the longitudinal reinforcement. PN 519 for Composite Fiber Wrap Systems references the International Code Council Evaluation Service website (www.icc-es.org) for acceptable FRP wrap products. Refer to the Designer Notes for plan information associated with this work. 303.2 PEDESTRIAN AND BIKEWAY 64B STRUCTURES C303.2 The H15-44 vehicle accommodates the largest emergency vehicles that may access a pedestrian facility. Design pedestrian and bikeway structures in accordance with the latest edition of the AASHTO LRFD Guide Specifications for the Design of Pedestrian Bridges and this Manual. Where sidewalks, pedestrian, and/or bicycle structures are intended to be used by maintenance and/or other incidental vehicles, include an H15-44 vehicle, as shown in BDM Figure 303-3, in the Design Loading. Do not include the H15-44 lane loading. Do not place the vehicle live load in combination with the pedestrian live load and do not apply the dynamic load allowance to the H15 vehicle. Position the design truck transversely such that the center of any wheel load is not closer than:
  • For the design of the deck overhang – 1.0-ft from the face of curb or railing and
  • For the design of all other components – 2.0-ft from the edge of the design lane. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-9 Figure 303-3 303.3 65BRAILROAD BRIDGES Design facilities, that are operated and maintained by the railroad, according to the specifications and design standards used by the railroad in its normal practice. Facilities that are operated and maintained by ODOT or other local agency shall conform to the AASHTO LRFD Bridge Design Specifications and this Manual. 304 11BMATERIALS 304.1 66BSTRUCTURAL STEEL C304.1 Select structural steel material from the following list: There are several systems available for coating steel bridges. These coatings are specified in C&MS 514 or by the plan notes available from the Office of Structural Engineering. See BDM Section 308.2.2.1.d.1 for guidelines on selecting a coating system. A. ASTM A709 Grade 50W B. ASTM A709 Grade 50 C. High Performance Steel (HPS), ASTM A709 Grade 70W Grade 50W shall be utilized for un-coated weathering steel applications. Grade 50 shall be utilized for coated steel bridges. Grade 70W is an un-coated weathering steel that is most economical when used in the flanges of hybrid girders. Consult the Office of Structural Engineering for recommendations prior to specifying its use. A plan note is available from the Office of Structural Engineering. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-10 Contact OSE if there are no domestic sources available for steel items listed in the Contract Documents. Common items involving domestic sourcing issues include highly specialized components such as: brakes for lift bridges; steel ferrules for suspension bridge cables; and components in movable bridge mechanisms. Determine the Estimated Quantities for structural steel pay items in accordance with the Method of Measurement specified in C&MS 513.29. Use of contingent quantities for secondary members shall be avoided. If contingencies of any kind are included in the Estimated Quantities, provide a Plan note clarifying how the contingent quantities were determined. 304.2 67BCONCRETE, CAST-IN-PLACE 304.2.1 178BCONCRETE DESIGN STRENGTHS C304.2.1 Use the following 28-day concrete strengths (f’c) for DESIGN purposes: A. Substructure Concrete (Class QC1) .............. 4.0-ksi B. Superstructure Concrete (Class QC2)........... 4.5-ksi C. Drilled Shaft Concrete (Class QC5) ............. 4.0-ksi The concrete used for drilled shafts is a 4.5-ksi mix design. However, since there is the potential for issues that cause a reduction in strength to arise during placement, a 500-psi reduction in the concrete strength shall be considered for design purposes. 304.2.2 179BCONCRETE FOR BRIDGES AND STRUCTURES C304.2.2 The following ODOT concrete types are available for substructure concrete sold under Item 511: A1. Class QC1 Concrete B1. Class QC1 Concrete with QC/QA C1. Class QC3 Special Concrete D1. Class QC4 Mass Concrete ODOT also has classes of concrete available for moderate setting (Class QC MS) and fast setting (Class QC FS) mixes which are primarily used in pavement applications. For projects where these mix designs may be necessary, use an Item 511 CONCRETE, MISC. pay item and provide a plan note to clarify the project requirements. The following ODOT concrete types are available for superstructure concrete sold under Item 511: A2. Class QC2 Concrete B2. Class QC2 Concrete with QC/QA C2. Class QC3 Special Concrete D2. Class QC4 Mass Concrete The following ODOT concrete types are available for drilled shaft concrete sold under Item 524: A3. Class QC4 Mass Concrete B3. Class QC5 Concrete Specify “Concrete with QC/QA” for the class of concrete when the total concrete quantity for that class exceeds 150-yd3. The total volume for a class of concrete (which may occur in multiple pay items) used in a single bridge is to be included when determining the need for QC/QA. For example, the Class QC1 concrete from the abutments and piers would need to be quantified together and considered for QC/QA. Specifying QC/QA for smaller quantities may be cost prohibitive. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-11 Specify Class QC3 Special Concrete when concrete strengths and/or permeability other than the QC1 or QC2 are necessary. Specify Class QC4 Mass Concrete when the minimum dimension for a concrete component is 5-ft or greater or the diameter of a drilled shaft is 7-ft or greater. 304.2.3 180BCONSTRUCTION JOINTS C304.2.3 Show all Construction Joint locations in the plans. Label joints as: A1. Construction Joint B1. Optional Construction Joint C1. Construction Joint, Roughened D1. Optional Construction Joint, Roughened Each plan specified Construction Joint location shall meet the Interface Shear Transfer – Shear Friction requirements specified in LRFD 5.7.4. A Construction Joint is a plane separating concrete placements that reach initial set at different times. An Optional Construction Joint is one that is placed at the Contractor’s discretion. A Construction Joint, Roughened, is one with a finished surface that is intentionally roughened to an amplitude of 0.25-in. C&MS 511.09 defines the following Construction Joint surface finishes: A1. Non-finished 1. Applies to horizontal surfaces or any other orientation that does not require forming. 2. For design purposes, the non-finished surface represents concrete placed against a clean concrete surface, free of laitance, but not intentionally roughened as defined in LRFD 5.7.4.4. B1. Form-finished 1. Applies to vertical surfaces or any other orientation that requires forming. This finish also applies to the Construction Joint created when placing concrete against an existing concrete surface, placed in a previous project unless otherwise specified in the Plans. 2. For design purposes, the form-finished surface represents concrete placed against a clean concrete surface, free of laitance, but not intentionally roughened as defined in LRFD 5.7.4.4. C1. Roughened 1. C&MS 511.09.A defines the acceptable roughened surface finish for plastic concrete and C&MS 511.09.B defines the acceptable roughened surface finish for hardened concrete. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-12 2. For design purposes, both C&MS 511.09 roughened surfaces represent concrete placed against a clean concrete surface, free of laitance, with surface intentionally roughened to an amplitude of 0.25-in as defined in LRFD 5.7.4.4. 3. C&MS 515.15 defines the acceptable surface finish for composite prestressed beams. For design purposes, the C&MS 515.15 composite surface finish represents a cast-in-place concrete slab on clean concrete girder surfaces, free of laitance with surface roughened to an amplitude of 0.25-in as defined in LRFD 5.7.4.4. Joints labeled in the plan as “Construction Joint” or “Optional Construction Joint” will receive a non-finished or form-finished surface depending upon orientation. Construction Joints may be necessary to facilitate construction; however, joints represent a potential plane of weakness in a concrete member. The best approach to locating joints is to minimize the number and, if possible, locate joints at areas of minimum stress. The recommended design approach to Construction Joints should be as follows: A2. For horizontal Construction Joints or any other orientation that does not require forming, design the joints using the following 4-step sequence:
  1. Determine if the interface shear capacity of a non-finished surface is sufficient for the specified joint location using the reinforcement and cross-section sized for shear and moment in the member.
  2. If additional interface shear capacity is required and the location of the joint cannot be moved to an area of lower stress, reconsider the interface shear capacity with a roughened finish.
  3. If additional interface shear capacity is still required, increase the interface shear reinforcement (Avf) crossing the shear plane and reconsider the interface shear capacity with a roughened finish.
  4. If interface shear capacity is still not met, a redesign of the cross-section is warranted. The surface treatment specified for Horizontal Construction Joints in the most recent revision dates of the Standard Bridge Drawings may be used without further analysis of the interface shear capacity. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-13 C2. For Construction Joints created when joining new concrete to concrete placed in a previous project, and the:
  5. Existing concrete surface was formed, troweled, or saw cut, design the joints using the following 3-step sequence: a. Determine if the interface shear capacity of a non-roughened surface is sufficient using non-shrink, non-metallic grout to anchor interface shear reinforcement in accordance with C&MS 510. b. If additional interface shear capacity is required specify the existing concrete surface to be intentionally roughened according to C&MS 511.09.B. c. If interface shear capacity is still not met, a redesign of the cross-section is warranted.
  6. Existing concrete surface was prepared with chipping hammers, design the joints using the following 3-step sequence: a. Determine if the interface shear capacity of a roughened surface is sufficient utilizing salvaged reinforcement across the shear plane. b. If additional interface shear capacity is required, specify additional non-shrink, non-metallic grout to anchor interface shear reinforcement in accordance with C&MS 510. c. If interface shear capacity is still not met, a redesign of the cross-section is warranted. When determining the area of concrete considered to be engaged in interface shear transfer (Acv), do not include the surface area of sawcut surfaces in the calculation of intentionally roughened surface area. Where practical, avoid horizontal Construction Joints in piers, abutments, and retaining walls. Otherwise locate horizontal joints 1-ft above the OHWM. If Keyways are specified in Construction Joints, provide a cross-sectional view of the concrete member to completely define all Keyway dimensions. Determine the factored shear resistance (Vr) of the Keyway as the least of the following: A Keyway is a Construction Joint requiring formwork to create a “tongue and groove” geometry between the different concrete placements. Keyways are not an effective mitigation method for water infiltration. A2. Factored bearing capacity on the shear key mating surfaces due to shear loading B2. Factored shear capacity on the dimension of shear key parallel to the shear loading BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-14 C2. Shear load inducing the Cracking Moment (Mcr) of the shear key due to the eccentricity of the shear loading located at the centroid of the shear key mating surfaces. If the factored shear resistance of the Keyway (Vr) is less than the factored interface shear resistance across the depth of the keyless Construction Joint (Vri), then the contribution of the Keyway shall be ignored. Specify Keyways in unreinforced Construction Joints and joints that serve the purpose of Contraction Joints. Locate the Construction Joint at the base of columns supported directly on drilled shafts in accordance with BDM Section 305.4.4. Provide Optional Construction Joints to avoid pier lift heights exceeding 30-ft. Detail reinforcement to be developed each side of the Optional Construction Joint. Consider the use of Construction Joints for the following issues: A3. To avoid or minimize member dimensions defined in BDM Section 304.2.2 that require Mass Concrete provisions. B3. To accommodate standard concrete formwork construction practices and concrete member geometry changes. For example, Construction Joints may allow a Contractor to utilize a prior concrete placement for formwork support to complete a substructure unit. C3. To accommodate construction sequencing. For example, a Construction Joint in a T-type pier stem may allow the removal of cofferdam sheeting which would otherwise be obstructed by pier cap concrete placed directly above. Seal all Construction Joints in contact with fill above the footings and below the approach slab on the back of abutments, wingwalls and retaining walls with ITEM 512, TYPE 2 WATERPROOFING, 3-ft wide centered on the joint. 304.3 68BCONCRETE, PRESTRESSED C304.3 Select a 28-day compressive strength ranging from 5.5-ksi to 7.0-ksi. Provide the 28-day compressive strength in the contract plan General Notes. Select a compressive strength at the time of release ranging from 4.0-ksi to 5.0-ksi. Provide the release strength in the contract plan General Notes. In order to specify a release or 28-day concrete strength that deviates from the ranges provided, contact the Ohio Prestressers Association and/or the PCI Central Region to request documentation that the deviation is acceptable and can be produced within the project timeframe by at least two independent producers prequalified under S1079. ODOT may request verification of this documentation during project reviews. Cast-in-place concrete used in prestressed concrete superstructures (composite decks, pier diaphragms, intermediate diaphragms, etc.) shall be Class QC2 or Class QC2 with QC/QA. Select Class QC2 or Class QC2 with QC/QA according to BDM Section 304.2.2. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-15 304.4 69BCONCRETE REINFORCEMENT 304.4.1 181BMATERIAL TYPES The Department will allow six types of material for use as concrete reinforcement: A. Uncoated Steel Reinforcement (USR) B. Epoxy Coated Steel Reinforcement (ECSR) C. Galvanized Steel Reinforcement (GSR) D. Glass Fiber Reinforced Polymer Reinforcement (GFRP) E. Chromium Steel Reinforcement (CSR) F. Stainless Steel Reinforcement (SSR) Acceptable designs for each of these materials will yield differing results for reinforcement ratio and/or development lengths. Except as noted in C&MS 709.16, the Department will require a Value Engineering Change Proposal according to C&MS 105.19 in order to consider substitution of concrete reinforcement types after the Contract sale date. The concrete reinforcement material type for new concrete members shall be defined in the Scope of Services. If the Scope of Services does not define the concrete reinforcement material type, then all reinforcement shall be ECSR according to BDM Section 304.4.1.2. 304.4.1.1 380BUNCOATED STEEL REINFORCEMENT C304.4.1.1 Uncoated Steel Reinforcement is available for use only in rehabilitation of existing concrete members. The Department will pay for USR as: ITEM 509 – UNCOATED STEEL REINFORCEMENT USR is intended for applications where the work consists of repair or rehabilitation of existing concrete members reinforced with uncoated reinforcement. USR may also be considered for replacement of damaged reinforcement after surface preparation for overlays involving hydro demolition or scarification. USR should also be considered for structural doweling applications into existing concrete according to C&MS 510. 304.4.1.2 381BEPOXY COATED STEEL REINFORCEMENT C304.4.1.2 Epoxy coated steel reinforcement shall be Grade 60, Fy = 60-ksi in accordance with C&MS 709.00 furnished from a Supplement 1068 certified supplier. Provide epoxy coated steel reinforcement except as noted in BDM Section 405.2 or unless otherwise noted in the Scope of Services. The advantages of ECSR include: A1. Provides increased corrosion protection above ordinary uncoated steel reinforcement. B1. Lowest cost corrosion protection for steel reinforcement C1. Shortest lead times for concrete reinforcement delivery BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-16 The Department will pay for ECSR as: ITEM 509 – EPOXY COATED STEEL REINFORCEMENT D1. Permits field fabrication (e.g. bending and cutting) E1. Damage to the coating is repairable F1. Readily available mechanical splice options The disadvantages of ECSR include: A2. Susceptible to coating damage during shipping, handling, installation and concrete placement. B2. Unrepaired damage to the epoxy coating may result in corrosion similar to or in some cases worse than uncoated steel. C2. Concrete bond strength to ECSR results in longer development lengths and potentially wider crack widths when compared to ordinary uncoated reinforcing steel. D2. ECSR coating will degrade with extended exposure to UV light reducing the coating thickness and causing embrittlement. E2. ECSR coating may be completely removed if exposed to the hydro-demolition surface preparation for deck overlays. 304.4.1.3 382BGALVANIZED STEEL REINFORCEMENT C304.4.1.3 Galvanized steel reinforcement shall be Grade 60, Fy = 60-ksi in accordance with C&MS 709.16 furnished from a Supplement 1068 certified supplier. The Department will pay for GSR as ITEM 509 – GALVANIZED STEEL REINFORCEMENT. Two types of galvanized coating systems are available: ASTM A767 and ASTM A1094. ASTM A767 reinforcement is normal uncoated reinforcement that is fabricated then sent to a hot-dip galvanizer for coating. ASTM A1094 reinforcement is coated in a continuous galvanizing process before it is sent to the bar fabricator for cutting and bending. This process saves time and freight by eliminating the trip to the galvanizer after fabrication. The fabricator is responsible for repairing the coating on ends of bars cut during the fabrication process. The advantages of GSR include: A1. Unlike ECSR, unrepaired damage to GSR bars that occurs during shipping, handling, installation, or concrete placement will be protected by galvanic corrosion. B1. Structural development lengths are equal to ordinary uncoated steel reinforcement and shorter than ECSR. C1. The introduction of the continuously galvanized reinforcement has enabled GSR to be more cost competitive with ECSR. D1. Permits field fabrication (e.g. bending and cutting) BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-17 The disadvantages of GSR include: A2. Corrosion will occur on improperly coated ends of continuously galvanized reinforcement damaged during fabrication. B2. GSR lead times for delivery longer than ECSR. For hot dipped GSR, fabricated reinforcement needs to be shipped to galvanizer for coating. For continuously GSR, prefabricated reinforcement needs to ship from sole supplier in Oklahoma. C2. Initial cost of GSR higher than ECSR. D2. The galvanized coating may be completely removed if exposed to the hydro-demolition surface preparation for deck overlays. E2. The minimum bend diameters for ASTM A767 bars are larger than ASTM A1094, USR, ECSR, CSR and SSR. 304.4.1.4 383BGFRP REINFORCEMENT C304.4.1.4 GFRP reinforcement shall be in accordance with C&MS 705.28 furnished from a Supplement 1138 certified supplier. GFRP reinforcement shall only be utilized for the following applications: The advantages of GFRP reinforcement include: A1. GFRP reinforcement is much lighter than steel reinforcement resulting in lower shipping, handling, and installation costs. A. Reinforcement in concrete decks for Beam-Slab bridges B. Longitudinal reinforcement in concrete bridge railings C. Spiral and tie reinforcement in axial compression members D. Reinforcement in approach slabs B1. Deterioration of GFRP reinforcement is negligible over the life of the structure. C1. GFRP reinforcement is very cost competitive to ECSR. The Department will pay for GFRP reinforcement as: ITEM 509 - NO. __ DEFORMED GFRP REINFORCEMENT. The Department will not permit concrete removal using hydrodemoltion for any Corrective Work Plans involving new concrete members reinforced with GFRP reinforcement. The disadvantages of GFRP reinforcement include: A2. GFRP reinforcement does not have a well-defined yield point. This lack of ductility precludes its use as primary tension reinforcement in many applications .B2. GFRP reinforcement has more limited availability for bent shapes compared to other material types. Bent bars for sizes #9 and #10 are not available. Also, vertical reinforcement in standard concrete bridge railing includes bend diameters smaller than permitted for GFRP reinforcement and bar shapes not available in GFRP reinforcement. C2. An approved mechanical splice attached directly to GFRP reinforcement is not available. Mechanical splices to steel reinforcement then lapped to GFRP reinforcement provides an acceptable alternative. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-18 D2. Concrete repair work (e.g. hydro-demolition and chipping hammers) can irreparably damage GFRP reinforcement. ODOT has performed an acceptable hydro-demolition surface preparation on concrete reinforced with GFRP, but some damage to the reinforcement is likely. Test sections are necessary to determine machine settings for optimal results. E2. GFRP reinforcement will deform more due to its lower elastic modulus than steel reinforcement. F2. Does not permit field fabrication (e.g. bending and cutting) 304.4.1.5 384BCHROMIUM STEEL REINFORCEMENT C304.4.1.5 Chromium steel reinforcement is available in three alloy types distinguished by their chromium content: A. Type CL (2 - 3.9% Cr) B. Type CM (4 – 7.9% Cr) C. Type CS (8 – 10.9% Cr) CSR shall be Grade 100, Fy = 100-ksi in accordance with C&MS 709.17 furnished from a Supplement 1068 certified supplier. Specify the Type and Grade in the Plans. Do not use CSR Grade 120. The Department will pay for CSR as: ITEM 509 – CHROMIUM STEEL REINFORCEMENT, TYPE Chromium steel reinforcement offers a higher level of protection against corrosion than ordinary uncoated steel reinforcement due to its chemical composition. A measure of corrosion resistance available for steel reinforcement is the quantity of chloride in concrete that initiates corrosion commonly referred to as the chloride threshold (CT). Literature for chromium steel reinforcement suggests that Type CL has a CT 1.5 times greater than ordinary uncoated steel reinforcement; Type CM has a CT 2.0 times greater; and Type CS has a CT 4.0 times greater. C&MS 709.17 specifies Type CS if not otherwise specified in the Plans. The advantages of CSR include: A1. CSR provides three different levels of corrosion protection that exceed the corrosion resistance of ordinary uncoated steel reinforcement. Type CL provides slightly less protection than undamaged ECSR while Type CM provides slightly more protection. B1. CSR’s higher strength can be utilized to reduce congestion and development lengths of ordinary reinforcement. CSR is available in Grade 120, Fy = 120-ksi, but AASHTO does not permit steel reinforcement above 100-ksi. C1. The bars have no coating that can be damaged during shipping, handling, installation, concrete placement, hand chipping and hydro-demolition. D1. Permits field fabrication (e.g. bending and cutting) The disadvantages of CSR include: A2. CSR has a higher unit cost than ECSR. The cost of CSR increases with increases in chromium content. Type CL having the lowest cost and Type CS the highest cost. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-19 B2. CSR is not produced locally so availability could be an issue and lead times would be longer than ECSR. 304.4.1.6 385BSTAINLESS STEEL REINFORCEMENT C304.4.1.6 Stainless steel reinforcement shall be Grade 75, Fy = 75-ksi in accordance with C&MS 709.18 furnished from a Supplement 1068 certified supplier. The Department will pay for SSR as: ITEM 509 – STAINLESS STEEL REINFORCEMENT. SSR reinforcement weighs slightly less than ordinary steel reinforcement. Refer to ASTM A955 Table 1 for more information. The advantages of SSR include: A1. SSR offers the highest level of corrosion protection for concrete reinforcement available. The bars have no coating that can be damaged during shipping, handling, installation, concrete placement, hand chipping, and hydro-demolition. B1. Structural development lengths are equal to ordinary uncoated steel reinforcement and shorter than ECSR. C1. Permits field fabrication (e.g. bending and cutting) The disadvantages of SSR include: A2. AASHTO will not permit the use of SSR above Seismic Zone 1 or in areas where plastic hinging is expected. B2. Equipment used to handle and fabricate stainless steel needs to be kept separate from that used to fabricate carbon steel reinforcement. C2. SSR availability could be an issue and lead times would be longer than ECSR. D2. Requires stainless steel or plastic ties. E2. SSR has the highest initial cost for the reinforcement types listed in BDM Section 304.4.1 304.4.2 182BMAXIMUM LENGTH C304.4.2 The maximum length of fabricated concrete reinforcement shall not exceed 60-ft. The practical maximum length of concrete reinforcement is 40-ft. This limit is for both transit purposes and construction convenience. To facilitate an economical design using 60-ft bar stock, where multiple sets of lapped bars are required (e.g. longitudinal slab reinforcement) consideration should be given to using multiple sets of 30-ft long bars. For bent or radial bars, the maximum dimension from a straight line between the ends of the bar and the apex of the bar shall not exceed 7.5-ft, See BDM Figure 304-1. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-20 Figure 304-1 304.4.3 183B AR MARKS C304.4.3 Provide unique Bar Marks on detail plans to identify the bar's size and general location and to reference the bar to the reinforcing bar list. Incorporate letters into the bar marks to help identify their location in the detail plans: "A" for abutments, "P" for piers, "S" for superstructure, “SP” for spirals, “DS” for drilled shafts, etc. Provide a note or legend with the bar list to describe each Bar Mark's meaning. Use the following abbreviations to denote the bar material: USR, ECSR, GSR, GFRP, CSR, or SSR. See BDM Figure 304-2. Examples: An A501 bar mark represents a #5 abutment bar. An SP401 bar mark represents a #4 spiral bar. A DS901 bar mark represents a #9 drilled shaft bar. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-21 Figure 304-2 BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-22 304.4.4 184BLAP SPLICES C304.4.4 Detail bar splice lengths on the plans. Development and splice lengths shall conform to AASHTO requirements. Where a horizontal construction joint is used in a column or pier, the reinforcement should be continuous, and splices avoided if at all possible. An exception to this is the construction joint between a column and a footing, where the reinforcement should be discontinuous and adequate splice length should be furnished. For compression splice lengths of epoxy coated steel reinforcement, see BDM Figure 304-3. For tension splice lengths of epoxy coated steel reinforcement, see BDM Figure 304-4. For development length requirements for epoxy coated steel reinforcement, see BDM Figure 304-3, Figure 304-4 & Figure 304-5. Figure 304-3 BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-23 Figure 304-4 BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-24 Figure 304-5 Lap spliced reinforcement shall extend through a phased construction joint at least the required splice length. Consider additional extension for bars extending through a vertical construction joint to allow for placement tolerance. Do not extend concrete reinforcement through expansion and contraction joints. 304.4.5 185BMECHANICAL SPLICES C304.4.5 Mechanical splices are an acceptable alternative to lap splices. Mechanical splices shall be in accordance with the requirements of C&MS 509. When mechanical splices are required, designate which bar(s) will have mechanical splice(s) in the bar list. When specifying mechanical splices in congested areas, consider staggering splice locations in order to meet the minimum spacing of concrete reinforcement according to LRFD 5.10.3.1. Specify only mechanical type splices for bar sizes #14 and larger. The Department will not permit lap splices for these bar sizes. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-25 The Department will not permit splicing of reinforcing by welding unless otherwise noted. 304.4.6 186BMECHANICAL ANCHORING C304.4.6 Mechanical anchoring, such as headed reinforcing, is permitted. Design headed anchor in accordance with ACI 318-14 25.4.4. The AASHTO LRFD Bridge Design Specification does not currently have a formal specification for mechanical anchorage, however their use is permitted in LRFD 5.10.8.3. 304.4.7 187BLENGTHS AND WEIGHTS OF REINFORCEMENT C304.4.7 Calculate concrete reinforcement lengths to the nearest 1-in. Use the criteria specified in C&MS 509 to calculate standard bend lengths. The length or height of a spiral is defined as the distance out-to-out of coils, including the finishing turns at top and bottom. Calculate and include the weight of the additional 1-1/2 coils of spiral required at the end by LRFD 5.10.4.2 in the estimated quantities. For one, #4 spiral with a 4-1/2-in pitch, the weight, including the 1½ coils at each end, is given by the following formula: 𝑊𝑊 = 0.148𝜋𝜋𝜋𝜋�� 4.5 2 � 2
  • (𝐷𝐷 − 0.5)2
  • 0.167𝜋𝜋(𝐷𝐷 − 0.5) Where: W = Spiral Weight (lb) D = Outside Diameter of the Spiral (in) H = Height or Length of the Spiral (ft) See BDM Figure 304-6 for area, weight and diameter of standard reinforcing. See BDM Figure 304-7 for bar bending data. See BDM Figure 304-8 for standard bar length deductions of common bends. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-26 Figure 304-6 Bar Bending Data (Dimensions in inches) Bar Size D A H C D A J J-A D A H 3 2.25 5 4.00 3.00 2.25 5.0 6 1.0 1.50 4.00 2.50 4 3.00 6 4.50 4.00 3.00 7.0 8 1.0 2.00 4.50 3.00 5 3.75 7 5.00 5.00 3.75 8.5 10 1.5 2.50 5.50 3.75 6 4.50 8 5.75 6.00 4.50 10.0 12 2.0 4.50 8.00 4.50 7 5.25 10 7.50 7.00 5.25 12.0 14 2.0 5.25 9.00 5.25 8 6.00 11 8.00 8.00 6.00 13.5 16 2.5 6.00 10.50 6.00 9 9.50 15 10.00 11.75 9.50 15.5 19 3.5 - - - 10 10.75 17 11.50 13.25 10.75 18.0 22 4.0 - - - 11 12.00 19 12.75 14.75 12.00 20.0 24 4.0 - - - 14 18.25 27 17.25 21.75 18.25 25.0 31 6.0 - - - 18 24.00 36 23.25 28.50 24.00 33.0 41 8.0 - - - Bending Tolerances: Refer to ACI 318 & CRSI Manual of Standard Practice Figure 304-7 BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-27 Figure 304-8 304.4.8 188BCONCRETE REINFORCEMENT BAR LIST C304.4.8 Include the following in the bar lists: A1. Bar Mark B1. Number of bars required C1. Overall length of each bar D1. Total weight or length for each bar mark E1. Column for type/shape of bar:
  1. "ST" for straight, or 2. Number assigned to “Bending Diagram" F1. "Number" and "Series" for series bars G1. Identify bars with mechanical splices A sample bar list is provided in BDM Figure 304-2. Identify each bent bar by a unique number and illustrate in the “Bending Diagram”. Define dimensions for the bent bars by letters A through Z. Also include spiral reinforcing in the detail plan's bar list. Provide the following information on the bar list: BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-28 A2. Core diameter B2. Pitch C2. Mark D2. Number E2. Height F2. Weight 304.4.9 189BCORROSION PROTECTION C304.4.9 Unless noted in the Scope of Services or as noted in BDM Section 405.2, provide epoxy coated steel reinforcement in all cast-in-place concrete. Provide epoxy coated reinforcing steel for all approach slabs. The concrete reinforcement material for approach slabs should match that used in the superstructure concrete. The design provided by AS-1-15 does not apply to approach slabs reinforced with GFRP, Stainless Steel or Chromium Steel reinforcement. 304.4.10 190BMINIMUM COVER FOR CONCRETE REINFORCEMENT The minimum concrete cover shall be as follows: A. Bridge decks*, slab bridges* and sidewalks (top surface) .................................................... 2.50-in B. Bridge decks and slab bridges (bottom surface) .................................................... 1.50-in C. Footings (bottom surface) ................................ 3-in D. Approach slabs (top & bottom surfaces) .......... 3-in E. Column ties or spirals ....................................... 3-in F. Drilled shaft ties/spirals (dia. ≤ 3-ft) ................ 3-in G. Drilled shaft ties/spirals (3-ft < dia. < 5-ft) ...... 4-in H. Drilled shaft ties/spirals (dia. ≥ 5-ft) ................ 6-in I. Prestressed I-beams & Box beams (side & bottom surfaces) 1.25-in J. Prestressed Box Beams (inside surfaces) ......... 1-in K. All other concrete surfaces .............................. 2-in
    • The 1.0-in monolithic wearing surface is included in the minimum cover shown Provide clearances in the detail plans for areas not defined in C&MS 509.04, C&MS 524 or referenced Standard Bridge Drawing. 304.4.11 191BMINIMUM CONCRETE REINFORCEMENT Near exposed surfaces of walls and slabs not otherwise reinforced, provide minimum reinforcement for shrinkage and temperature according the AASHTO requirements. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-29 304.5 70BPRESTRESSING STEEL 304.5.1 192BTYPE & SIZE Use the following type and size strand for prestressed box beam members: Low-relaxation 0.520-in diameter (AS = 0.167-in2) seven wire uncoated strands, ASTM A416, Grade 270. Use the following type and size strand for prestressed I-beam members: Low-relaxation, 0.600-in diameter (AS = 0.217-in2) seven wire uncoated strands, ASTM A416, Grade 270. Provide the prestressing strand type and size in the contract plan General Notes. 304.5.2 193BSTRESSES Initial prestressing loads for low-relaxation strand shall be as follows: Initial stress ................................. 0.75 f′s = 202.5-ksi Initial tension load: A. AS = 0.167-in2 ................................ 33.750-kip/strand B. AS = 0.217-in2 ................................ 43.950-kip/strand 305 12BFOUNDATIONS 305.1 71BGENERAL DISCUSSION C305.1 Analyze all structure foundations for external stability in the Strength Limit State and for vertical and horizontal movements in the Service Limit State according to LRFD Section 10 or 11, as applicable. Meet all the subsurface exploration requirements for structures according to Section 300 of the SGE. For footings supported on deep foundations, neglect bearing resistance of the footing concrete on soil. External stability analyses include: bearing resistance; eccentric load limitations; overturning analyses; sliding resistance; and overall stability. 305.1.1 194BOVERALL STABILITY C305.1.1 Analyze overall (global) stability for each structure at critical locations according to LRFD 10.5.5.2.1 and 11.6.3.7, with the following exceptions: Factored loads are incompatible with limit equilibrium analysis. A. Do not use factored loads for the analyses B. Use the following resistance factors for the analyses: BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-30 Design all bridge substructure units and tiered retaining wall systems for overall stability using a resistance factor of φ = 0.65. Design all other retaining walls for overall stability using a resistance factor of φ = 0.75. Resistance factors as shown in LRFD 11.6.2.3 should be taken as the inverse of the following factors of safety (FS) for the case of limit equilibrium slope stability analysis only: A. φ = 0.75 corresponds to FS = 1.3 B. φ = 0.65 corresponds to FS = 1.5 305.1.2 195BLATERAL LOADING ON DEEP FOUNDATIONS C305.1.2 Perform a p-y analysis when analyzing deep foundations (such as driven piles, drilled shafts, micropiles, or continuous flight auger piles) under lateral loading. A p-y analysis should be performed using a derivative of the COM624P program (e.g. LPILE). The p-y analysis provides the expected lateral displacement, as well as shear and moment load effects in the deep foundation element due to applied lateral loading, moment, and displacement. For abutments supported on MSE walls that utilize MSE reinforcements attached to the back of the abutment footing to resist lateral loading, the p-y analysis is not necessary. For footings with battered piles designed to resist the for lateral loads, the p-y analysis is not necessary. See BDM Section 305.3.5.8 regarding the use of battered piles. For stub abutment walls of 10-ft or less in height, no p-y analysis is necessary as long as there is no scour extending below the bottom of footing, since the lateral load will not be enough to substantially effect the piles. If a p-y analysis of the piles in the construction condition (without the superstructure installed) shows excessive stresses or deflection in the piles, provide plan notes regarding sequence of construction and limiting the placement of backfill behind the abutments before placement of the superstructure. For rehabilitation of existing full-height integral superstructures, provide plan notes to require excavation of the backfill prior to removal of the superstructure. In the case of full-height integral abutments, the critical state will occur when there is earth pressure on the back of the abutment prior to having the superstructure in place to act as a lateral brace. C&MS 516.07 will allow backfilling to the level of the beam seat prior to the completion of bearings connections. For integral construction, the superstructure will not act as a brace until the end diaphragms are complete. Designers should verify that the deep foundation elements have the capacity to resist this loading condition. For all integral abutments in the in-service condition (with the superstructure installed), if the piles have the minimum length specified in ICD-1-20 or ICD-2-18, no p-y analysis is necessary. Otherwise, perform p-y analyses combining the thermal deflection of the superstructure with the lateral earth and surcharge loads to check if the piles will experience excessive stresses. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-31 For deep foundation elements spaced closer than 5 diameters center to center, include group effects. Apply group effects only within the soil overburden length of the deep foundation. Do not apply to rock sockets. Group effects for a single row of deep foundation elements under lateral loads (with the load oriented perpendicular to the axis of the row) can be ignored when the deep foundation elements are placed at a center-to-center spacing of 3.75 diameters or greater. For deep foundation elements spaced closer together, utilize a reduction factor as calculated in the following equation, per “Analysis and Design of Shallow and Deep Foundations” (Reese, Isenhower, and Wang, 2006): Pm = 0.64 (S/B)0.34 for 1.0 ≤ S/B ≤ 3.75 Where: Pm = p-multiplier S = center-to-center spacing of deep foundation elements B = diameter of deep foundation element For multiple rows of deep foundation elements, see LRFD 10.7.2.4 for values of Pm. See FHWA GEC 10, Section 11.5.1, Table 11-1 regarding p-multipliers with a more comprehensive table of values for drilled shafts; use these same Pm for other drilled deep foundation elements (CFA piles or micropiles). When lateral loads are controlling the design of drilled shafts, perform lateral load testing according to the Scope of Services. Consult the Office of Geotechnical Engineering regarding specifications for lateral load testing in the Scope of Services. To evaluate lateral deflection in the Strength Limit State (overturning resistance) see BDM Section 307.1.4. Do not analyze deep foundations with the “Geotechnical Strength Limit State” analysis, per publication FHWA-NHI-10-016, Geotechnical Engineering Circular 10 (GEC 10) “Drilled Shafts: Construction Procedures and LRFD Design Methods,” Section 12.3.3.3.1. To evaluate lateral deflection in the Service Limit State, see BDM Section 305.1.3. The “Geotechnical Strength Limit State” analysis is over-conservative for consideration of overturning stability of deep foundations. 305.1.3 196BVERTICAL AND HORIZONTAL MOVEMENTS C305.1.3 Analyze foundation settlement according to LRFD 10.5.2.2. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-32 In addition to the requirements for serviceability provided in LRFD C10.5.2.2, use the following criteria to establish acceptable settlement criteria: Consider the following methods for remediation to limit structural deformations due to settlement: increasing the foundation dimensions, excavating and replacing the foundation soils, adjusting the construction sequence, specifying waiting periods, application of surcharge loads, the use of deep foundations, or ground improvement. Wick drains or other subsurface drainage may be utilized to accelerate the rate of settlement. Select the method for settlement remediation based on the type of structure and time, space, and cost considerations. Refer to BDM Section 600 for applicable plan notes. A Special Provision for Installation of Wick Drains is available from the Office of Geotechnical Engineering. A. The angular rotation caused by differential settlement between adjacent substructures shall not exceed 0.004 radians. B. The maximum differential settlement (Δ) between adjacent substructures supporting continuous steel superstructures shall be: ∆= 0.55 𝐿𝐿 𝑆𝑆� − 2.6 < 8.0 Reference: Moon, F.L., N. Romano, D. Masceri, J. Braley, N. Samtani, T. Murphy, M. Lopez de Murphy, and D.R. Mertz. 2017. Bridge Superstructure Tolerance to Total and Differential Foundation Movements. National Highway Cooperative Research Program (NCHRP), Web-only Document 245: http://www.trb.org/Publications/Blurbs/177297.aspx In which: Δ = Maximum differential settlement (in) L = Shortest adjacent span length (ft) S = Beam/Girder spacing (ft) C. The maximum differential settlement (Δ) between adjacent substructures supporting prestressed concrete beams with a continuous deck shall be: ∆= 0.13 𝐿𝐿 𝑆𝑆� − 0.17 < 2.5 In which: Δ = Maximum differential settlement (in) L = Shortest adjacent span length (ft) S = Beam/Girder spacing (ft) The limiting values of 8.0-in and 2.5-in are provided due to the range of applicability noted in the report referenced above for the equations shown. If long-term settlements encroach upon the required minimum vertical clearance, make necessary adjustments to the vertical profile. Vertical and horizontal movements of abutment walls shall meet the limits of BDM Section 307.1.6. For lateral displacement of foundations that support bridge structures, bridge serviceability limits shall control. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-33 305.1.4 197BGROUND IMPROVEMENTS C305.1.4 If analyses demonstrate inadequate foundation stability (bearing, sliding, or lateral resistance; overall stability; or settlement) consider using ground improvement techniques to improve the foundation soils. Refer to the Transportation Research Board SHRP2 Geotech Tools website at http://www.geotechtools.org/ for a comprehensive list of ground improvement techniques. Refer to FHWA-NHI-16-027/FHWA-NHI-16-028, Geotechnical Engineering Circular 13 (GEC 13) “Ground Modification Methods Reference Manual” for guidance on design for ground improvement techniques. Consider ground improvements for resistance of horizontal forces for structures with shallow foundations only after the improvements recommended in BDM Section 305.2.1.3 or BDM Section 307.1.3 are found to be not cost effective. Consult with the Office of Geotechnical Engineering if considering ground improvement techniques. 305.1.5 198BSEISMIC DESIGN C305.1.5 Analyze soil borings to identify overlying soil profiles that can amplify ground motion propagating from underlying rock and use the Site Class Definition as specified in LRFD 3.10.3.1 for determination of seismic design parameters on a site-by-site basis. Use blow counts corrected to an equivalent rod energy ratio of 60%, N60, as defined in the SGE for the average SPT blow count 𝑁𝑁�. In the absence of sufficient geotechnical information, assume Site Class D for the project soil profile. Refer to BDM Section 303.1.4.1 for additional design requirements for bridges located in Site Class D, E or F. Use the Seismic maps, LRFD Figures 3.10.2.1-1 through 3.10.2.1-3 or the USGS US Seismic Design Maps web application using latitude and longitude to determine the seismologic data for a project location (PGA, SS, and S1). Use the Site Factors for Site Class D in lieu of the Site Factors provided in LRFD 3.10.3.2 for Site Class E and F. In other words, for the entire State of Ohio, assume Fpga ≤ 1.6, Fa ≤ 1.6, and FV ≤ 2.4. The site-specific procedure, per LRFD 3.10.2.2 is not required for Ohio. For all other Site Class types, use Site Factors as defined in LRFD 3.10.3.2. The entire State of Ohio is assumed to have a Peak Ground Acceleration Coefficient (PGA) above 0.03g but less than 0.06g, a Short-Period Horizontal Response Spectral Acceleration Coefficient (SS) above 0.072g but less than 0.134g, and a Long-Period Horizontal Response Spectral Acceleration Coefficient (S1) above 0.03g but less than 0.05g. In other words, per the provisions of LRFD 3.10.3.2, PGA < 0.10, SS < 0.25, and S1 < 0.1 for the entire State of Ohio. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-34 If sufficient geotechnical information is not available to determine Site Class for new substructure units, and the project is located in areas where S1 ≥ 0.042, then assume 0.1 ≤ SD1 < 0.15. Otherwise, assume SD1 < 0.10 and AS ≥ 0.05. For Ohio, only areas where S1 ≥ 0.042, as shown in BDM Figure 305-1, and Site Class D, E or F exist, will 0.10 ≤ SD1 < 0.15. In Seismic Performance Zone 1, for 0.10 ≤ SD1 < 0.15, according to LRFD 5.11.2, refer to BDM Section 303.1.4.1 for additional connection and reinforcement detailing requirements. In Seismic Performance Zone 1, according to LRFD 3.10.9.2, the magnitude of the horizontal design connection force in the restrained directions is defined in relation to whether AS is greater or less than 0.05. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-35 Figure 305-1 BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-36 If sufficient geotechnical information is not available to determine Site Class for rehabilitation projects refer to BDM Section 303.1.4.2. See BDM Section 303.1.4.1 for additional seismic analysis and design requirements. 305.1.6 199BSCOUR C305.1.6 All foundation requirements shall be satisfied for the changes in conditions resulting from the scour design flood at the strength and service limit states and the scour check flood at the extreme event limit states. Determine the design flood frequency and the check flood frequency for scour, in accordance with L&D, Vol. 2, Section 1008.10.5. Ignore Rock Channel Protection in the prediction of scour depths. The changes in foundation conditions resulting from scour do not apply to the overall (global) stability 305.1.7 200BRESISTANCE FACTORS Use resistance factors for different types of deep foundation systems for design at the strength limit state as specified in BDM Table 305-1. Additional resistance factors can be found in LRFD 10.5.5.2. Where resistance factors in BDM Table 305-1 differ from those in LRFD 10.5.5.2, the values in BDM Table 305-1 override. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-37 Table 305-1 Method/Soil/Condition Resistance Factors Driven Drilled Micro- CFA Piles Shafts Piles Piles Nominal Axial Compressive 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-38 305.2 72BSPREAD FOOTINGS 305.2.1 201BGENERAL DISCUSSION C305.2.1 Design spread footings for piers in accordance with LRFD Section 10. Design spread footings for abutments and retaining walls in accordance with LRFD Section 11. Optimize spread footing dimensions for the controlling Limit State. The use of spread footings should be based on the following: depth and strength of suitable bearing materials; ease of construction; potential effects of phased construction; effects of flooding and scour; liquefaction and swelling potential of the soils; frost depth; and amount of predicted settlement versus tolerable structure movement. If placing spread footings on soil, consider the effects of primary and secondary settlements on long-term maintenance costs of the structure and appurtenances and the effects on ride quality. Refer to BDM Section 201.2.1.3 for information to include in the Structure Foundation Exploration Report. LRFD Equation 10.6.3.1.2a-1 clarification of γq and γf is no longer necessary. This change is incorporated in the LRFD Bridge Design Specifications, 9th Edition (2020). For the calculation of the depth correction factor dq used in LRFD Equation 10.6.3.1.2a-3, use the following equation: dq = 1 + 2 tan φf (1-sin φf)2 arctan (Df /B) Where: dq = depth correction factor (dim) φf = angle of internal friction of soil (deg.) Df = footing embedment depth (ft) B = footing width (ft) arctan (Df/B) is in radians. Use this equation without any limits on the values of φf, Df, B, or Df /B, regardless of the limits imposed in LRFD 10.6.3.1.2a. The equation is per “A Revised and Extended Formula for Bearing Capacity” (Hansen, 1970). For the case of vertical or inclined eccentric loading, assume the values of ic = iq = iγ = 1.00. For the case of inclined centric loading, use LRFD Equations 10.6.3.1.2a-5 through 10.6.3.1.2a-9 for the calculation of ic, iq, and iγ. Do not use spread footing supported structures on MSE walls. Spread footings are susceptible to loss of bearing caused by erosion during the service life of the structure. 305.2.1.1 386BSETTLEMENT C305.2.1.1 For all spread footings, perform a settlement analysis according to LRFD 10.6.2.4. See BDM Section 305.1.3 for limits on vertical movement with respect to a supported bridge structure. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-39 Where significant settlement of a spread footing is predicted that would affect the serviceability of the supported structure, provide elevation reference monuments. See BDM Section 600 for notes and additional guidance. Significant settlement is defined as that exceeding the serviceability limits in BDM Sections 305.1.3 or 307.1.6. Elevation reference monuments are for the purpose of measuring footing elevations during and after construction to document the performance of the spread footings, both short term and long term. 305.2.1.2 387BMINIMUM DEPTH AND SCOUR CONSIDERATIONS 305.2.1.2.a 524BSPREAD FOOTING ELEVATIONS FOR FOUNDATIONS LOCATED OUTSIDE THE LIMITS OF THE 100-YR FLOOD PLAIN The following requirements apply to spread footings located outside of the plan view limits of the 100-yr flood plain: A. For footings founded on rock, key the bottom of footings at least 3-in into rock. B. Embed the tops of footings founded on soil at least 1-ft from the nearest soil surface. C. Embed the bottoms of footings founded on soil at least 4-ft from the nearest soil surface. D. Embed the bottoms of footings founded on embankment fill at least 5-ft from the nearest soil surface. See BDM Figure 305-2. E. In no case shall the bottom of the footings in existing soil or on embankment fills be above the frost line. Refer to BDM Figure 305-3 to determine the frost depth at the project site in inches. If the project site lies between two contour lines, choose the contour line with the greater frost penetration depth. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-40 Figure 305-2 BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-41 Figure 305-3 BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-42 305.2.1.2.b 525BSPREAD FOOTING ELEVATIONS FOR FOUNDATIONS INSIDE THE LIMITS OF THE 100-YR FLOOD PLAIN C305.2.1.2.b The following requirements apply to spread footings located inside of the plan view limits of the 100-yr flood plain: A. Locate the footings for 3-Sided Flat Top and Arch Section Culvert structure types (C&MS 706.051 and 706.052) according to GDM Section 1400. B. Except as noted in BDM Section 305.2.1.2.b.(A), locate the bottom of footings directly on scour resistant rock. If footings require lateral restraint, provide drilled and grouted steel anchors. Scour resistant rock shall have the following properties to an elevation at least 4-ft below the Thalweg:
  1. Unconfined compressive strength, Qu ≥ 2500-psi, per ASTM D7012, Method C
  2. Slake Durability Index, SDI ≥ 90%, per ASTM D4644
  3. Rock Quality Designation, RQD ≥ 65%, per SGE Section 6
  4. Total Unit weight ≥ 150-pcf
  5. Rock Mass Strength Properties: a. Rock Mass Rating, RMR ≥ 75 or b. Geologic Strength Index, GSI ≥ 75 with Very Good or Good Joint Surface Conditions and Massive or Blocky Structure
  6. Erodibility Index, K ≥ 100, per publication FHWA-HIF-12-003 (HEC 18) “Evaluating Scour at Bridges,” Section 4.7.2, where: a. K = (Ms)(Kb)(Kd)(Js), Kb = RQD/Jn ≥ 0.10, and Kd = Jr/Ja Where RQD = 0, Block Size Parameter Kb = RQD/Jn = 0, and subsequently Erodibility Index K = 0. In the scour calculations that depend on K, it is in the denominator, and K = 0 will result in a divide by zero error. b. For the Intact Rock Mass Strength Parameter, Ms, use the following equations: i. Ms = Qu for Qu ≥ 10-MPa, or ii. Ms = (0.78) Qu 1.05 for Qu < 10-MPa, where iii. Qu is in units of MPa, per USBR publication "Best Practices in Dam and Levee Safety Risk Analysis," Chapter IV-1. c. If the Rock Joint Set Number, Jn, cannot be determined from observation or bore hole data, then assume Jn = 5. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-43 d. If the Joint Roughness Number, Jr, cannot be determined from observation or bore hole data, then assume Jr = 1. e. If the Joint Alteration Number, Ja, cannot be determined from observation or bore hole data, then assume Ja = 5. f. If the Relative Joint Orientation Parameter, Js, cannot be determined from observation or bore hole data, then assume Js = 0.4.
  7. For interbedded rock formations, consider only the weaker material.
  8. No Ordovician bedrock formation may be considered as scour resistant rock. C. Except as noted in BDM Section 305.2.1.2.b.(A), locate the bottom of footings founded on non-scour resistant rock at least one foot below the rock scour depth as calculated according to HEC 18. If historical evidence of scour deeper than the calculated depth in the rock foundation material at or near the footing location is available, spread footings foundations shall not be used. D. Except as noted in BDM Section 305.2.1.2.b.(A), footings founded on soil are prohibited. For substructures founded on deep foundations not socketed into bedrock, extend the piles or drilled shafts to at least 15-ft below either the Thalweg elevation or the maximum estimated scour depth, whichever is deeper. For drilled shafts socketed into bedrock, see BDM Section 305.4.1.1. E. At the design flood scour condition, evaluate the foundations at the Strength I Limit State for structural strength and external stability. 305.2.1.2.c 526BSPREAD FOOTING ELEVATIONS FOR FOUNDATIONS INSIDE THE LIMITS OF THE 500-YR FLOOD PLAIN The following requirements apply to spread footings located inside of the plan view limits of the 500-yr flood plain: A. At the check flood, evaluate the foundations at the Extreme Event II Limit State for structural strength and external stability. B. Include live loads on the structure and foundations (LL and LS), and water load from stream pressure (WA). C. Include the maximum estimated scour depth at the check flood, considering any streambed or bank material displaced by scour from the check flood. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-44 D. All Resistance Factors shall be assumed to be 1.00 for the Extreme Event II Limit State analysis with the check flood. 305.2.1.3 388BRESISTANCE TO HORIZONTAL FORCES C305.2.1.3 If the sliding resistance of the foundation material is inadequate to withstand the horizontal forces, as determined in accordance with LRFD 10.6.3.4, provide additional resistance using one or more of the following means, listed in order of preference: A. Increase the footing width. B. Use a footing shear key and utilize only the passive pressure acting on the key. Locate the shear key within the middle two-thirds of the footing width. C. Use deep-foundation supported footings. For footings supported on deep foundations, neglect frictional resistance of the footing concrete on soil. D. Use ground anchors, struts, deadmen, or soil reinforcements. Extend these elements outside the active failure wedge of the footing or retaining wall. Use only the portion of the horizontal resistance located outside of the active wedge. Soil reinforcements are generally geogrids or metallic reinforcements that are typically used for mechanically stabilized earth structures. Do not utilize passive resistance against sliding unless the foundation penetrates below frost depth or soil disturbance. See LRFD 11.6.3.5. The opposite is also the case: passive resistance can be used if the foundation penetrates below frost depth or probable soil disturbance. 305.2.1.4 389BCONCRETE REINFORCEMENT C305.2.1.4 Locate bottom transverse footing reinforcement (i.e. reinforcement parallel to the centerline of the substructure) at the minimum concrete cover. Locate bottom longitudinal footing reinforcement (i.e. reinforcement perpendicular to the centerline of the substructure) above the bottom transverse footing reinforcement. Footings for this provision include spread footings and footings supported on deep foundations. Refer to BDM Section 304.4.10 for concrete cover requirements. Locate the hooks for footing dowels in the plane of the bottom mat of footing concrete reinforcement. Footing dowels are the reinforcement that laps with the primary (vertical) steel in the substructure unit. This provision provides a location to tie the footing dowel reinforcement. For piers located within embankment slopes, the minimum footing dowel reinforcement ratio shall be 0.79-in2/ft. Otherwise the minimum footing dowel reinforcement ratio shall be 0.44-in2/ft. Provide a minimum reinforcement ratio of 0.20 in2/ft at the following footing locations: A. The bottom of the toe and the top of the heel of a spread footing for a cantilever retaining wall or abutment. B. The top of all pier footings. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-45 305.2.1.5 390BDESIGN CONSIDERATIONS C305.2.1.5 For cap and column piers on spread footings placed on existing soils or on embankment fills, provide continuous footings which extend beyond the center of the end column a distance equal to approximately 1/3 of the distance between the end column and the adjacent column. The continuous footing requirement provides resistance to differential settlement between columns. The footing dimension requirement provides approximately balanced moments. For cap and column piers with spread footings on bedrock provide separate footings under each column For grade separation structures, locate the top of pier footings in accordance with BDM Section 305.2.1.2. The spread footing width for a pier shall not be less than one-fourth the height of the pier where founded on soil and not less than one-fifth the height of the pier where founded on bedrock. Measure the pier height from the bottom of the footing to the top of the highest beam seat. The minimum width of abutment and retaining wall spread footings founded on soil shall be one-half the wall height (H). There is no minimum width for abutment and retaining wall spread footings founded on bedrock. Refer to LRFD Figure 11.6.3.2-1 for a definition of (H). For semi-integral abutments, measure the height to the beam seat for this purpose. 305.2.2 202BSPREAD FOOTINGS ON COHESIONLESS SOILS For spread footings founded on cohesionless soils, determine settlement due to the incremental loading during the construction sequence. 305.2.3 203BSPREAD FOOTINGS ON COHESIVE SOILS C305.2.3 Do not found spread footings for piers and abutments on cohesive soils with Undrained Shear Strength (Su) less than 2.0-ksf. There is no limitation on Su for foundation soils under spread footings for all other types of retaining walls. This limitation also does not apply to culvert headwall and wing wall spread footing foundations. Refer to GDM Section 1400 for guidance. Do not found spread footings on cohesive soils when secondary settlements will directly affect the performance of the structure over its service life. 305.2.4 204BSPREAD FOOTINGS ON BEDROCK C305.2.4 Use φτ = 0.9 as the sliding resistance factor for pier footings founded on weak or very weak bedrock (Qu < 1.5-ksi). A sliding resistance check may be non-performed for footings keyed 3-in into slightly strong or stronger bedrock (Qu ≥ 1.5-ksi), as long as there is no evidence of features of the bedrock structure that may constitute planes of weakness such as laminations or interbedding. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-46 305.3 73BDRIVEN PILES 305.3.1 205BGENERAL DISCUSSION C305.3.1 Design driven piles in accordance with LRFD 10.7 and install in accordance with C&MS 507 and 523. Consider driven piles when they become economically viable, or if they are needed for resistance against lateral and uplift loads. If artesian conditions are encountered, consult with the Office of Geotechnical Engineering regarding pile type selection. Refer to BDM Section 201.2.1.3 for information to include in the Structure Foundation Exploration Report. For the piles in each substructure unit, provide the following in the structure general notes: A. For piles driven to refusal on bedrock, the total factored load in axial compression. B. For friction piles, the Ultimate Bearing Value (UBV). C. For laterally loaded piles, externally applied lateral loads and bending moments, and maximum values of internal shear and moment. Provide a unique number designation for each pile in the plans. 305.3.1.1 391BPILE TYPES C305.3.1.1 Steel H-piles shall meet the requirements of ASTM A572 Grade 50. The commonly available steel H-pile sizes are HP10x42, HP12x53, and HP14x73. Refer to the AISC Steel Construction Manual for section properties of available H-piles. Cast-in-place (CIP) reinforced concrete pipe piles shall meet the requirements of ASTM A252 for steel pipe piles Grade 2 (Fy = 35-ksi) or Grade 3 (Fy = 45-ksi). Do not use Grade 1 steel pipe piles. Closed-end CIP reinforced concrete pipe piles shall not exceed 24-in nominal diameter. The Department will define large-diameter open-ended pipe piles as having a minimum 36-in nominal outside diameter. The commonly available closed-end CIP reinforced concrete pipe pile sizes are 12-in, 14-in, and 16-in nominal diameter. Refer to publication FHWA-NHI-16-009/FHWA-NHI-16-010, Geotechnical Engineering Circular 12 (GEC 12) “Design and Construction of Driven Pile Foundations” for section properties of available CIP reinforced concrete piles. Specify the wall thickness and Grade of closed-end CIP reinforced concrete pipe piles. The minimum wall thickness is 0.250-in. Increase the wall thickness as necessary to avoid overstressing the pile during driving, as determined by the wave equation drivability analysis required in BDM Section 305.3.1.2. Start the drivability analysis for CIP piles with Grade 2 material and the minimum wall thickness. Before increasing the wall thickness, switch to Grade 3 material. Choose the appropriate sample Plan note in BDM Section 606 to specify the wall thickness. Specify the material Grade and strength in the Plan note for Design Data provided in BDM Section 602. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-47 It is preferable to specify a single wall thickness across smaller structures (one to three spans) whenever the piles are of the same diameter, so that the piles cannot be mixed up and the wrong piles installed at a substructure unit. If a structure has different size piles at the abutments and the pier(s) – for example 12-inch and 16-inch respectively – then different pile wall thicknesses can be reasonably specified for the two sizes without any worry of mixing up the piles by the pile installer. Detail large-diameter open-ended pipe piles as filled with Class QC1 concrete to the clean out elevation shown on the plans, after pile installation. Specify the Grade and the wall thickness and increase the thickness as necessary to avoid overstressing the pile during driving, as determined by the wave equation drivability analysis required in BDM Section 305.3.1.2. If considering large-diameter open-ended pipe piles, consult with the Office of Geotechnical Engineering. The soil inside large-diameter open-ended pipe piles should be removed to the elevation shown on the plans. Clean out requirements should be specified on the plans. Formation of the pile plug often does not occur in large-diameter open-ended pipe piles without providing a steel plate annulus to facilitate intentional plugging. Estimation of pile lengths should be based on an iterative, rigorous analysis, considering potential of pile plug formation during driving. The Department does not restrict the use of precast reinforced concrete piles or precast prestressed concrete piles. Currently no construction specifications exist for precast concrete piles.
