Development of a MASH Test Level 4 Steel, Side-Mounted, Beam-and-Post, Bridge Rail, TRP-03-410-20, Midwest Roadside Safety Facility, Nebraska Transportation Center, University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Lincoln, Nebraska. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-214 309.4.3 279BWHEN TO USE 309.4.3.1 456BNEW JERSEY SHAPE CONCRETE BRIDGE RAILING (36-in BR-1-13) C309.4.3.1 This railing system is acceptable for all bridges regardless of Major Maintenance responsibility except as noted below. The Department prefers the use of the 36-in Single Slope Concrete Bridge Railing (SBR-3-20) to the 36-in New Jersey Shaped Concrete Bridge Railing where possible. Do not specify 36-in New Jersey shaped bridge railing at the deck edge of a high-speed route with more than two lanes. This provision is consistent with BDM Section 309.4.1. Do not specify the 36-in New Jersey shaped bridge railing on a new bridge deck where the 42-in Single Slope Concrete Bridge Railing is acceptable. Even though the 36-in New Jersey shaped bridge railing has been tested and evaluated as a TL-3 MASH acceptable railing system, the Department would prefer to utilize the higher TL systems where they are applicable. The 36-in tall NJ shape should only be considered under the following circumstances: A. Locations where the 42-in Single Slope system causes a stopping sight distance issue. B. Locations where the structural capacity of existing superstructure will not accommodate the weight of the 42-in Single Slope system. For projects where both 36-in and 42-in railings are considered as noted above, the lowest cost alternative is acceptable. Include the following information in the project plans: plan views, elevation views, cross-sections, deflection joint spacing, deflection joint details, reinforcing marks, reinforcing bending diagrams, steel reinforcement weights and GFRP reinforcement lengths. Reference in the plans to the Standard Bridge Drawings is necessary for historical purposes only. Include provisions to collect and carry deck drainage off the ends of the bridge in the project plans Refer to the L&D, Vol. 2, Section 1113.1 for more information. 309.4.3.2 457BNEW JERSEY SHAPE CONCRETE BRIDGE RAILING (42-in BR-1-13) C309.4.3.2 This railing system is acceptable only for bridges carrying non-NHS routes where Major Maintenance is not ODOT’s responsibility. The 42-in New Jersey shaped bridge railing has not been tested or evaluated to the MASH acceptance criteria. Use the 42-in Single Slope Concrete Bridge Railing in lieu of the 42-in NJ shape railing on bridges carrying NHS routes and where ODOT has Major Maintenance responsibility. Include the following information in the project plans: plan views, elevation views, cross-sections, deflection joint spacing, deflection joint details, reinforcing marks, reinforcing bending diagrams, steel reinforcement weights and GFRP reinforcement lengths. Include provisions to collect and carry deck drainage off the ends of the bridge in the project plans. Refer to the L&D, Vol. 2, Section 1113.1 for more information. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-215 309.4.3.3 458B RIDGE SIDEWALK RAILING (BR-2-15) C309.4.3.3 This railing system is acceptable for all bridges regardless of Major Maintenance responsibility except as noted below. This railing system is for use on bridges with sidewalks at least 5-ft wide and a curb height of 8-in. Although this system is essentially a combination railing system, it may also be used without a sidewalk in applications where pedestrian traffic is not a concern. For projects with sidewalk railing and Vandal Protection Fencing, BR-2-15 provides a modified base plate that includes a welded post sleeve for any VPF-1-90 post section. Do not specify this railing system at the deck edge of a high-speed route with more than two lanes. This provision is consistent with BDM Section 309.4.1. Include the following information in the project plans: plan views, elevation views, cross-sections, deflection joint spacing, deflection joint details, reinforcing marks, reinforcing bending diagrams and steel reinforcement weights. Include provisions to collect and carry deck drainage off the ends of the bridge in the project plans. Refer to the L&D, Vol. 2, Section 1103.8 for more information. 309.4.3.4 459BDEEP BEAM BRIDGE GUARDRAIL (DBR-2-73) C309.4.3.4 This railing is acceptable only for bridges over waterways carrying non-NHS routes where Major Maintenance is not ODOT’s responsibility except as noted below. Do not specify the DBR-2-73 railing system on bridges carrying High-speed routes. The original DBR-2-73 railing was tested under the NCHRP Report 230 acceptance criteria using a 2000-lb car at a speed of 60-mph with a 20° impact angle and a 4500-lb car at a speed of 60-mph with a 25° impact angle(1). That acceptance level was grandfathered to a TL-2 acceptance level under NCHRP Report 350 because the performance of the TL-3 vehicle is unknown. The use of the Deep Beam Bridge Guardrail with the Deep Beam Retrofit Railing (DBR-3-11) is acceptable in accordance with BDM Section 0 (1) Bronstad, M.E., Michie, J.D. and Mayer, J.D. 1987. Performance of Longitudinal Traffic Barriers, NCHRP Report 289, Transportation Research Board, National Research Council, Washington, DC. Variable post lengths may be required along the length of a structure due to beam camber. Retired design data sheet, DBP-1-92, is available from the Office of Structural Engineering Archived Standard Drawings website to address these concerns. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-216 309.4.3.5 460BDEEP BEAM BRIDGE RETROFIT RAILING (DBR-3-11) C309.4.3.5 This railing system when used in combination with the Deep Beam Bridge Railing, DBR-2-73, on new bridge decks is acceptable only for bridges carrying non-NHS routes over waterways where Major Maintenance is not ODOT’s responsibility. Refer to BDM Section 403.10.1.3.e for applications on existing bridges. The Deep Beam Bridge Retrofit Railing system was evaluated under the NCHRP Report 350 acceptance criteria(1). There is no design speed restriction associated with the use of the Deep Beam Bridge Retrofit Railing system. (1) Abu-Odeh, A.Y., Williams, W.F., Buth, C.E., Kim, K.M. 2010. Development of a TL-3 Deep Beam Tubular Backup Bridge Rail, Texas Transportation Institute, Texas A&M University, Bryan, Texas. To transition the Deep Beam Retrofit Railing to Type MGS approach roadway guardrail, use an ODOT Type 4 Bridge Terminal Assembly as detailed on Plan Insert Sheet GR-3.4 with a revision date of July 20, 2018. At the end of the Type 4 BTA, transition to MGS using SCD MGS-4.3 followed by SCD MGS-2.1. The top of w-beam element for the Deep Beam Bridge Railing and the Type 4 BTA is located at 27.75-in above the pavement surface. For standard Type MGS guardrail, the top of the w-beam element is located at 31-in above the pavement surface. Detail this height transition to occur in the shortest horizontal distance possible beyond the BTA Type 4 and within the first four panels of Type MGS guardrail. 309.4.3.6 461BPORTABLE CONCRETE BARRIER (PCB-91 & RM-4.2) C309.4.3.6 The project plans shall include the following information: plan view showing the location of the portable barrier along the entire length of the bridge; typical section showing lane widths and deck width; anchoring requirements for both PCB-91 and RM-4.2 barrier sections; and the appropriate pay item. RM-4.2 was evaluated under MASH acceptance criteria and the PCB-91 barrier system was evaluated under NCRHP Report 350 acceptance criteria. A joint implementation agreement between AASHTO and FHWA established a deadline for the use of non-MASH accepted portable barrier systems.(1) Under the agreement, the Department cannot allow the use of PCB-91 segments cast after December 31, 2019. PCB-91 segments cast prior to that date may be utilized until December 31, 2029. Since contractors are permitted to use existing PCB-91 or RM-4.2 segments, the plans need to address anchoring requirements for both systems. (1) Everett, T., Griffith, M.S., January 7, 2016. Joint Implementation Agreement for Manual for Assessing Safety Hardware (MASH), AASHTO/FHWA, Office of Safety, Federal Highway Administration, Washington D.C. Placement of unanchored PCB-91 and RM-4.2 on bridge decks and the anchoring requirements for PCB-91 are defined in Design Data Sheet, PCB-DD available at the OSE website. The anchoring requirements for RM-4.2 are provided on sheet 4 of the drawing. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-217 The Department will pay for portable concrete barrier as follows: ITEM 622 – PORTABLE BARRIER, UNANCHORED ITEM 622 – PORTABLE BARRIER, ANCHORED When anchoring to the bridge deck is required for any temporary railing system, note in the plans that railing sections that span an expansion joint shall only be anchored on one side of the expansion joint. C&MS 622 does allow the Contractor to substitute an ODOT approved alternative portable barrier product listed on the Office of Roadway Engineering’s website. Designers should become familiar with these approved products to ensure their potential use is not detrimental for a specific project. Provide Plan notes restricting these products where required. 309.4.3.7 462BSINGLE SLOPE CONCRETE BRIDGE RAILING (SBR-1-20) C309.4.3.7 The SBR-1-20 railing system is acceptable for all bridges regardless of Major Maintenance responsibility Include the following information in the project plans: plan views, elevation views, cross-sections, deflection joint spacing, deflection joint details, reinforcing marks, reinforcing bending diagrams, steel reinforcement weights and GFRP reinforcement lengths. Include provisions to collect and carry deck drainage off the ends of the bridge in the project plans. 309.4.3.8 463B57-in SINGLE SLOPE CONCRETE MEDIAN BRIDGE RAILING (SBR-2-20) C309.4.3.8 The SBR-2-20 railing system is acceptable for all bridges regardless of Major Maintenance responsibility The unreinforced 57-in median bridge railing is based on the barrier detailed in SCD RM-4.3. The acceptance of the reinforced 57-in median bridge railing is based on the Final Report for NCHRP Project No. 20-07/Task 395. Include the following information in the project plans: plan views, elevation views, cross-sections, deflection joint spacing, deflection joint details, reinforcing marks, reinforcing bending diagrams, steel reinforcement weights and GFRP reinforcement lengths. List GFRP reinforcement in the Reinforcement Schedule. The Department will pay for GFRP by total length in feet for each bar size under Item 509. Include provisions to collect and carry deck drainage off the ends of the bridge in the project plans. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-218 309.4.3.9 464BTWIN STEEL TUBE BRIDGE RAILING (TST-1-99) C309.4.3.9 This railing system is acceptable only for bridges over waterways carrying non-NHS routes where Major Maintenance is not ODOT’s responsibility. The Twin Steel Tube Bridge Railing is a modified version of the Illinois DOT Type SM system which was tested according to the AASHTO Guide Specifications for Bridge Railing using an 1800-lb car at 60-mph with a 20° impact angle; a 5400-lb pickup truck at 60-mph with a 20° impact angle; and an 18000-lb single unit truck at 50-mph with a 15° impact angle.(1) (1) Buth, C.E., Hirsch, T.J. and Menges, W.L. 1997. Testing of New Bridge Rail and Transition Designs Volume I; Technical Report, Texas Transportation Institute, College Station, Texas This rail type does not meet the minimum requirements specified by AASHTO for pedestrian and bicycle railings and shall not be used where pedestrian or bicycle traffic is expected. For box beam bridge types, reference post spacing dimensions to each box beam end. The typical post spacing is 6.25-ft. The standard drawing allows a reduced span for the first, last and one additional post spacing per span on each side of the bridge to account for construction clearances. Carefully review the position of the posts that are near the corner of a structure for possible interference with wingwalls, tie rods, etc. The site plan shall show the station of the center of the first inlet-mounted post on each corner of the bridge. 309.4.3.10 465BSINGLE SLOPE CONCRETE BRIDGE RAILING (SBR-3-20) C309.4.3.10 The SBR-3-20 railing system is acceptable for all bridges regardless of Major Maintenance responsibility except as noted below. Do not use the SBR-3-20 railing system at the deck edge of a bridge carrying a High-speed route of more than two lanes. A Low-speed route is a route with a Design Speed ≤ 45 mph. A High-speed route is defined in BDM Section 309.4.1. The SBR-3-20 railing system may be considered for bridges where the taller 42-in SBR-2-20 railing system presents sight distance issues. The lighter weight SBR-3-20 railing system may also be useful on rehabilitation projects where the existing deck is to remain. Include the following information in the project plans: plan views, elevation views, cross-sections, deflection joint spacing, deflection joint details, reinforcing marks, reinforcing bending diagrams, reinforcing steel weights and GFRP reinforcement lengths. Include provisions to collect and carry deck drainage off the ends of the bridge in the project plans. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-219 309.4.3.11 466BTHRIE BEAM RETROFIT RAILING (TBR-1-11) C309.4.3.11 This railing system is acceptable for retrofitting Safety Curb railing systems on all existing bridges regardless of Major Maintenance responsibility. This railing system is not acceptable for use on bridges receiving a new: deck, deck edge or superstructure. Refer to BDM Section 403.10.1.3.g for installation and maintenance requirements for TBR-1-11 bridge railing. Refer to BDM Section 403.10.1.3.g for additional description of the TBR-1-11 railing system. 309.4.3.12 467BTHREE STEEL TUBE BRIDGE RAILING (TST-2-21) C309.4.3.12 This railing system is acceptable for all bridges over waterways regardless of Major Maintenance responsibility except as noted below. Do not use the TST-2-21 railing system on bridges carrying a High-speed route of more than two lanes. The Three Steel Tube Bridge Railing system was developed as a joint research project between ODOT and the Illinois Department of Transportation at the Midwest Roadside Safety Facility.(1)(2)(3)(4) (1) Mauricio, P., Rasmussen, J.D., Faller, R.K., Rosenbaugh, S.K., Bielenberg, R.W., Peña, O., Steelman, J.S., and Stolle, C.S. 2020. Development of a Post-to-Deck Connection for a TL-4 Steel-Tube Bridge Rail. TRP-03-409-20. Midwest Roadside Safety Facility, Nebraska Transportation Center, University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Lincoln, Nebraska. (2) Pena, O., Faller, R. K., Rasmussen, J.D., Steelman, J.S., Rosenbaugh, S.K., Bielenberg, R.W., Mauricio, P., and Duren, J.T. 2020. Development of a MASH Test Level 4 Steel, Side-Mounted, Beam-and-Post, Bridge Rail. TRP-03-410-20. Midwest Roadside Safety Facility, Nebraska Transportation Center, University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Lincoln, Nebraska. (3) Rasmussen, J.D., Rosenbaugh, S.K., Faller, R.K., Alvarado, R., Mauricio, P., Bielenberg, R.W., and Steelman, J.S. 2020. Development of a MASH TL-3 Approach Guardrail Transition to a MASH TL-4 Steel Bridge Rail. TRP-03-411-20. Midwest Roadside Safety Facility, Nebraska Transportation Center, University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Lincoln, Nebraska. (4) Rosenbaugh, S.K., Rasmussen, J.D., Faller, R.K., Bielenberg, R.W., and Steelman, J.S. 2021. Steel Railing, Type IL-OH: MASH Evaluation and Implementation Guidance. TRP-03-438-21. Midwest Roadside Safety Facility, Nebraska Transportation Center, University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Lincoln, Nebraska. Reference Standard Construction Drawing, MGS-3.3, for the proper bridge terminal assembly. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-220 The Site Plan shall show the station of the center of the first post located off the bridge at each corner of the structure. For box beam superstructures, reference post spacing dimensions to each box beam end. The maximum post spacing is 8.0-ft which can be reduced to fit the span layout provided for the project. Carefully review the position of the posts that are near the corner of a structure for possible interference with wingwalls, tie rods, etc. Refer to TST-2-21 for specific clearance requirements. 309.4.4 280BSEALING OF CONRETE SURFACES, RAILING In addition to the requirements of BDM Section 309.2.1, seal all exposed surfaces of continuously reinforced concrete railing with an approved concrete sealer per C&MS 512. 309.5 99BFENCING 309.5.1 281BGENERAL C309.5.1 The primary purposes of protective fencing are to provide security for pedestrians and to discourage the throwing or dropping of objects from bridges onto traffic below. VPF-1-90 provides standard details for fencing attached to bridges. The designer may need to enhance this standard to deal with requirements for the specific structure. 309.5.2 282BWHEN TO USE C309.5.2 Install fencing on all bridges over vehicular and pedestrian traffic except as noted herein. Do not install fencing on bridges that carry freeways as defined in the ORC 4511.01 where pedestrians are prohibited per ORC 4511.051, unless otherwise specified in the Scope of Services. For facilities not defined as freeways by the ORC, use BDM Table 309-3. Install fencing on bridges over rail traffic if required in an agreement with the affected railroad. For existing bridges meeting the fencing requirements of this section, install the fencing when new concrete bridge railings are installed. Fencing should not be installed on existing concrete railings that are not in good condition. At locations where fencing will adversely affect public safety (e.g. reduced sight distance), submit a written request for exemption to the Administrator of the Office of Structural Engineering. Include supporting documentation with the request for exemption. An exemption request form is available as a Design Data Sheet on the Office of Structural Engineering web page. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-221 Table 309-3 Under Bridge Feature Fence Required Interstate Yes US Route Yes State Route Yes County\Township Route Yes City Route Yes Railroad Yes/No (Based on RR agreement) Waterway No Bike/Walking path No 309.5.3 283BFENCING CONFIGURATIONS C309.5.3 For structures without sidewalks, the minimum fence height is 8-ft above the pavement surface. For structures with sidewalks, the minimum fence height is 8-ft above the sidewalk. For curved fence, extend the post vertically for at least 8-ft above the sidewalk before curving inward over the sidewalk. Construct the overhang at least 1-ft less than the width of the sidewalk. See BDM Figure 309-27 & Figure 309-28. For a greater degree of protection against objects being thrown from the bridge, the fence may be curved to overhang the sidewalk. For pedestrian bridges, use bent pipe frames with pipe bend radii of 24-in at the upper corners and start the radii at least 8-ft above the sidewalk surface. Start the fabric at the deck line, top of curb or concrete bridge railing and extend to at least the top of the bent portion of the frame. Omitting fabric on the top horizontal area of the frame may prevent an individual from walking on the top of the enclosure. See BDM Figure 309-29 for an illustration of this configuration. Alternatively, the frame may be designed to form a peak at the center of the structure, similar to a house roofline. Install the fence a maximum of 1-in above the top of the concrete bridge railing. Locate baseplates so that the adhesive anchors are a minimum of 1.5 times the post-installed anchor embedment from the deflection joint of the railing Install posts and frames either plumb or perpendicular to the longitudinal grade of the bridge, subject to considerations of aesthetics or practicality of construction. For non-standard systems, show the posts and frames orientation with respect to the longitudinal grade in the plans. Provide complete details of base plates, pipe inserts or other types of base anchorage in the plans. VPF-1-90 is shown as plumb to the longitudinal grade. Extend the fencing between end posts placed at the locations selected from the following list that creates the shortest length: A. 30-ft ± 2.5-ft beyond the route under bridge edge of traveled way nearest the fence terminal BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-222 B. The centerline of the abutment expansion joint (-2.5-ft, + 0-ft) C. The end of the bridge railing (-2.5-ft, +0-ft) Place fence on structures parallel to traffic and that carry sidewalks located 30-ft or less from the nearest edge of the traveled way below. For bridges where a snooper truck will be used for inspection, use only straight fence with the top of the fence located 10-ft or less above the deck. Figure 309-27 BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-223 Figure 309-28 BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-224 Figure 309-29 309.5.4 284BSPECIAL DESIGNS C For fence installation projects on new structures, install a traffic railing (steel tubing) when the top concrete bridge railing or concrete wall is less than 36-in above roadway for structures without sidewalks or 36-in above the top of sidewalk for structures with sidewalks. See BDM Figure 309-27. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-225 Utilize a two coat shop applied epoxy/urethane system in accordance with C&MS 708.02 for color coating of posts and rails. Plan notes for this coating system are available from OSE upon request. Where the standard gray chain link fence mesh detracts from a project’s aesthetic enhancements, designers may select an optional color from the following: green, olive green, brown and black. For special fence designs, provide plan notes to define non-standard color, materials, traffic maintenance, construction procedures and other requirements. The designer should follow the example of standard bridge drawing for development of required notes. 309.5.5 285BFENCE DESIGN REQUIREMENTS 309.5.5.1 468BGENERAL Furnish fencing mesh with either of the following materials: A. Chain-link wire mesh with 1-in diamonds. The core wire shall be 11 gage with a Polyvinyl chloride coating. (C&MS 710.03) B. Welded wire fabric with 1/2-in x 3-in opening size. The core wire shall be 10.5 gage; galvanized after welding (1.2-oz zinc/ft²), and PVC coated (10-mil). Clamp brace and bottom rails to posts or post frames. Detail the top rail, if any, of a free-standing fence as continuous over two or more posts and provide suitable cap fittings. Bent pipe frames for narrow pedestrian bridges are permitted. Fabricate bent pipe frames for narrow pedestrian bridges in two or more sections and field spliced at the top with sleeves bolted to the frame sections. To prevent pipe blow-ups during galvanizing, leave both ends of pipe open. Therefore, put holes in the base plates equal to the pipes’ inside diameter. 309.5.5.2 469BWIND & PEDESTRIAN LOADS C309.5.5.2 Design non-standard chain link fence designs with loading in accordance with LRFD 13.8.2. Additional area for posts, rails and other hardware need not be considered. For decorative railing that includes lettering and/or other appurtenances, determine the appropriate wind pressure per LRFD 3.8 and apply the loading to the wind contact area for each appurtenance including the area for the posts and rails. The loading provisions in LRFD 13.8.2 for chain link fencing should not be used in addition to the wind loading per LRFD 3.8. 309.5.5.3 470BADHESIVE ANCHOR DESIGN When the fencing design is not according to VPF-1-90, design the post installed anchors using an adhesive anchor system. Mechanical anchors are not permitted. For additional information in the design of adhesive anchor systems, refer to BDM Section 406.1. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-226 Design the adhesive anchor system in accordance with LRFD 5.13. Provide an adhesive anchor system that has been evaluated by ICC-ES. Design anchors assuming cracked concrete. 309.5.6 286BTEMPORARY VANDAL PROTECTION FENCING C309.5.6 Use the Design Data Sheet, TVPFDD-1-18, Temporary Vandal Protection Fencing to determine the fencing requirements on bridges during construction. The intent of temporary vandal protection fencing is to discourage pedestrians from dropping or throwing heavy objects off the side of the bridge onto traffic below during construction. Standard Bridge Drawing, TVPF-1-18, Temporary Vandal Protection Fencing, provides details for: A. Type A – Fencing installed on existing railing systems and on the existing deck surface near the phased construction joint B. Type B – Fencing installed on the back side of the PCB. Refer to BDM Section 309.4.3.6 for PCB anchoring requirements. As a minimum, provide at least one anchor per PCB segment on the traffic side of the barrier. C. Type C – Fencing installed along the phased construction joint side of a newly constructed deck. Detail the length of the temporary vandal protection fencing installation in accordance with the minimum lengths defined in BDM Section 309.5.3. The Department will utilize permanent vandal protection fencing where possible to minimize costs for temporary fencing. Therefore, place new permanent fence installations prior to shifting traffic onto that phase of construction. Leave temporary vandal protection fencing installed on existing concrete railing in place until the concrete railing is removed from the bridge. Leave all other types of temporary vandal protection fencing in place until the Engineer determines that it is no longer necessary. Once removed, reinstallation of temporary vandal protection fencing is not required. In the plans provide pay item(s) in the Estimated Quantities; show the limits and location of each temporary vandal protection fencing installation; and show the appropriate temporary vandal protection fencing type on the Maintenance of Traffic Transverse Sections. If necessary, provide all non-standard connection and fence details in the plans; address special installation sequencing; and include all other special notes. Provide details for temporary vandal protection fencing across intermediate expansion joints. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-227 309.6 100BEXPANSION DEVICES 309.6.1 287BGENERAL C309.6.1 Use an expansion device that provides a total seal against penetration and moisture. Standard bridge drawings are available for expansion devices for typical bridge superstructure types. For fabricated steel expansion devices, specify the type of steel required. Include the type of steel in a plan note if the plan requirements are not covered by a selected standard bridge drawing. To protect steel expansion devices, metallize the exposed surfaces per C&MS 516. 309.6.1.1 471BPAY ITEM C309.6.1.1 Pay for expansion devices, except as specifically listed in this section, with an Item 516 pay item. For sealed expansion devices, pay for the elastomeric seal, either strip or compression with an Item 516 pay item. Clearly show what components are included with the expansion devices in the plans to be paid for with the Item 516 pay item. Consider the seal as part of the expansion device and included in the Item 516 pay item. As an example, cross-frames, which are field welded to both the superstructure girders and the expansion devices, are part of the Item 513 structural steel pay item. 309.6.1.2 472BEXPANSION DEVICES WITH SIDEWALKS C309.6.1.2 On structures with sidewalks, furnish the same expansion device on the side walk as utilized for main bridge deck expansion joint. For non-standard devices, use a curb plate and sidewalk cover plate. Separate the curb and sidewalk plates at the interface of the sidewalk and curb. Sidewalk details for standard expansion devices (strip seals) are shown on the standards. See details on Standard Bride Drawings: EXJ-2-81, EXJ-3-82, EXJ-4-87, EXJ-5-93 and EXJ-6-17 for sidewalk plates. 309.6.1.3 473BEXPANSION DEVICES WITH STAGE CONSTRUCTION On projects involving stage construction, locate and show joints in the seal armor in the plans. At the stage construction lines, use complete penetration welded butt joints to connect adjoining expansion devices. If butt welds will be in contact with a sealing gland, grind the butt-weld flush at the contact area. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-228 309.6.2 288BEXPANSION DEVICE TYPES 309.6.2.1 474BEXPANSION JOINTS USING POLYMER MODIFIED ASPHALT BINDER C309.6.2.1 Do not use polymer modified asphalt binder on structures with movement greater than 1-in or structures with sidewalks. This device is for use on structures with concrete or asphalt overlays and where total expected movement is 0-in to 1.0-in. See SS846 for additional information. Construct the polymer-modified joint to be between 2-in and 5-in thick. Show a plan view and cross-section of each polymer modified asphalt expansion joint location on the bridge in the plans. Provide the station of the joint centerline at the centerline of construction, skew angle and dimension its length as measured along the centerline of the joint in the plan view. Dimension the width and thickness of the joint, width of the expansion gap and other significant joint details in the cross-section. 309.6.2.2 475BSTRIP SEAL EXPANSION DEVICES C309.6.2.2 The seal size is limited to a 5-in maximum. Do not use unpainted A709 50W weathering steel in the manufacture of this type expansion device. Ensure that all details are covered in the plans because the standard drawing is not inclusive for all structure types. A709 50W does not perform well in the atmospheric conditions an expansion device is subjected. Standard Bridge Drawings, EXJ-4-87, EXJ-5-93 and EXJ-6-17, are available. Construct the strip seal in one piece across the total width of the structure. The Department will not permit splices. 309.6.2.3 476BCOMPRESSION SEAL EXPANSION DEVICES C309.6.2.3 The maximum allowable seal size is 4-in. Do not use a 5-in wide seal. Do not use compression seal expansion devices on structures with a skew greater than 15-degrees. Limit the movement so that the seal is not compressed greater than 60 percent or less than 20 percent. Installation problems have been encountered with the 5-in wide seal. Construct the compression seal in one piece across the total width of the structure. The Department will not permit splices. Standard Bridge Drawings EXJ-2-81 & EXJ-3-82 give generally used details 309.6.2.4 477BMODULAR EXPANSION DEVICES C309.6.2.4 Modular expansion devices may be required for structures when total required movements exceed movement capacity of a strip or compression seal. Modular expansion joint notes are available upon request. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-229 Design the modular devices main load bearing beams, support beams and welds for fatigue. Design of support for the modular device and deck thickness should allow for multiple styles or designs of modular devices. Contact suppliers and become familiar with the modular devices available. 309.6.2.5 478BTOOTH TYPE, FINGER TYPE OR NON-STANDARD SLIDING PLATE EXPANSION DEVICES C309.6.2.5 Finger or sliding plate joints are another alternative type of expansion device where movements exceed the capacity of either strip or compression seal devices. This type of expansion device generally competes against Modular joints. Their advantage is their simplicity of design. Their disadvantage is their inability to seal against intrusion of water and debris. Use of a tooth type expansion device also requires neoprene drainage troughs and a suitable drainage system to carry away the water. Completely detail both the neoprene trough and downspout to drainage trough connection. Pay special attention to developing a complete seal at the downspout to trough connection. Vulcanize the down spout to the trough. Design finger devices for fatigue. Do not design finger devices with fracture critical components. Use pre-qualified 513 Level UF fabricators to construct finger or sliding plate devices. Refer BDM Section 308.2.2.1.b for additional information. 309.6.3 289BEXPANSION DEVICE USES – BRIDGE OR ABUTMENT TYPE C309.6.3 Expansion length is defined as the total length if no fixed bearing exists, or length from fixed bearing to proposed expansion device location, if one exists. The expansion lengths shown in the table are approximate. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-230 Table 309-4 Bridge Type Expansion Length (ft) Bridge Joint Required Approach Slab/Structure Joint Type Approach Slab/Roadway Joint Type Reinforced Concrete Slab 0 - 160 None AS-1-15 detail B or C AS-2-15 Type A or B 160+ AS-2-15 Type C Steel Stringer 0 – 125* IA or EXJ-4-87 AS-1-15 detail B or C AS-2-15 Type A or B 125 – 400* IA AS-2-15 Type C EXJ-4-87 AS-2-15 Type A or B 400+ TTED or MED Prestressed Concrete I-Beam 0 – 160* IA or EXJ-6-17 AS-1-15 detail B or C AS-2-15 Type A or B 160 – 575* IA AS-1-15 detail B or C AS-2-15 Type C EXJ-6-17 AS-2-15 Type A or B 575+ TTED or MED AS-1-15 detail B or C AS-2-15 Type A or B Non-Composite Prestressed Concrete Box Beam 0 – 160* IA AS-1-15 detail E AS-2-15 Type A or B 160 – 475* AS-2-15 Type C Composite Prestressed Concrete Box Beam 0 – 160* IA or EXJ-5-93 AS-1-15 detail B or C AS-2-15 Type A or B 160 – 475* IA AS-2-15 Type C EXJ-5-93 AS-2-15 Type A or B 475 – 575* IA Non-standard Strip Seal TTED or MED AS-2-15 Type A or B 575+ TTED or MED AS-2-15 Type A or B IA = Integral/Semi-Integral Abutment TTED = Tooth Type expansion device PM = Polymer Modified Asphalt Joint MED = Modular Expansion Device * - “Expansion length” shown for integral and semi-integral superstructures refer to the total structure length to coincide with BDM Figure 306-5 and Figure 306-6. Otherwise, the expansion lengths shown refer to expansion lengths as define in BDM Section 309.6.3. Determine the expansion lengths for integral and semi-integral superstructures in accordance with BDM Sections 306.2.2.5 & 306.2.2.6, respectively. 309.7 101B RIDGE DECK DRAINAGE C309.7 When using concrete bridge railing, provide a minimum longitudinal grade of 0.3% across the entire length of the bridge deck surface. Minimize or eliminate scuppers used for collecting the deck surface drainage. Scupper should be eliminated on existing structure when feasible. Compute the allowable spread of flow using the procedures described in Section 1103 of the L&D, Vol. 2 to determine if scuppers are required. Scuppers when provided, should preferably be located inside the fascia beam. Slope drainage collection systems as steeply as practical, and not less than 15-degrees from horizontal. The minimum bend radius for the system is 18-in, and no 90-degree bends are permitted. Provide adequate pipe supports and cleanouts at the low ends of runs. The cleanout plugs should be easily and safely accessible. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-231 Place scuppers with drainage collection as closely as possible to the substructure unit which drains them. Locate and detail the drainage collection system in the plans. Place uncollected scupper downspouts as far away as possible from the substructure. When the deck drainage is to flow off the ends of the bridge, make provisions to collect and carry away this run-off. Refer to the L&D, Vol. 2, Section 1103.8 for more information. Control of drainage is especially critical at abutments with MSE walls. On structures with MSE walls at the abutments, provide a concrete bridge railing on the approach slab with a standard inlet, SCD I-3D to collect the drainage. Locate the inlet at least 25-ft beyond the limits of the MSE wall soil reinforcement and continue concrete barrier 10-ft past the catch basin. Refer to BDM Figure 309-30 for more information. For bridges with over-the-side drainage, provide a stainless steel drip strip to protect the deck edge and beam fascia from the deck surface run-off. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-232 Figure 309-30 309.8 102BSIDEWALKS & SHARED USE FACILITY C309.8 Provide a sidewalk when required by the L&D, Vol. 1, Section 306.4. The minimum width of the bridge sidewalk is the wider of: 5-ft or the approach sidewalk plus 12-in. Provide a 1.56 percent cross slope on the sidewalk towards the curbline. Provide an 8-in tall sidewalk on the bridge. Tapering the sidewalk curb down to the approach curb height may or may not be performed with the limits of the approach slab. Prepare a detail of the standard curb (height, face slope, and corner rounding) in the plans. 310 17BMISCELLANEOUS 310.1 103BTEMPORARY SHORING BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-233 310.1.1 290BSUPPORT OF EXISTING STRUCTURE Whenever temporary support is required for a portion of an existing structure used to maintain traffic, provide sufficient information in the plans to allow contractors to prepare bids and construct the project. Consider the feasibility of temporary support of an existing structure during the Structure Type Study. Include the following information in the plans: permissible locations of temporary support; temporary support loads; construction sequences; construction limitations not otherwise provided in C&MS 501.05; and all remaining plan notes. As a minimum, address method of measurement and basis of payment for temporary support in the plan notes. 310.2 104BAPPROACH SLABS Provide approach slabs for all ODOT bridges. 310.2.1 291BSTANDARD BRIDGE DRAWING – AS-1-15 C310.2.1 Standard Bridge Drawing, AS-1-15, provides contract ready designs and details of skewed and non-skewed approach slabs on tangent alignments with lengths of 15-ft, 20-ft, 25-ft and 30-ft under phased or non-phased construction. Determine the length of the approach slab using the following formula: L = [1.5(H + h + 1.5)] ÷ cos θ ≤ 30-ft Where: L = Length of the approach slab measured along the centerline of the roadway rounded up to the nearest 5-ft H = Height of the embankment measured from the bottom of the footing to the bottom of the approach slab (ft) h = Width of the footing heel (ft) θ = Skew angle For four lane divided highways on new embankment, provide an approach slab with a minimum length of 25-ft (measured along the roadway centerline). For structures with MSE walls at the abutments, provide an approach slab with a minimum length of 30-ft. For all other structures, provide an approach slab with a minimum length of 15-ft. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-234 310.2.1.1 479BPLAN REQUIREMENTS FOR STANDARD APPROACH SLABS When AS-1-15 is specified, provide the following information in the plans: A. Reference Standard Bridge Drawings: AS-1-15 and AS-2-15 B. Provide a plan view of the approach slab that includes: all width and length dimensions; skew angle; curb and concrete railing locations; and the final approach slab surface elevations at each transverse grade break line; phased construction line; and curbline/slab edge at each end of the approach slab. C. Include the D801 or D802 bars in the concrete reinforcement bar list for payment under Item 509. D. Include the appropriate pay item: ITEM 526 – REINFORCED CONCRETE APPROACH SLAB (T=__ ) or ITEM 526 – REINFORCED CONCRETE APPROACH SLAB WITHQC/QA (T=) E. Include pay ITEM 526 – TYPE __ INSTALLATION F. Include, as necessary, pay ITEM 846 – POLYMER MODIFIER ASPHALT EXPANSION JOINT SYSTEM or ITEM 516 – ARMORLESS PREFORMED JOINT SEAL For bridge replacement projects, when the existing approach slab is to be removed, include ITEM 202 – APPROACH SLAB REMOVED in the structures estimated quantities. 310.2.1.2 480BPLAN REQUIREMENTS FOR NON-STANDARD APPROACH SLABS C310.2.1.2 In addition to the plan requirements listed in BDM Section 310.2.1.1, provide all geometry and the reinforcement layout for the non-standard approach slab. Include these detail drawings in the structure plans for review during the detail design review stage. Include the appropriate pay item: ITEM 526 – REINFORCED CONCRETE APPROACH SLAB (T=), AS PER PLAN or ITEM 526 – REINFORCED CONCRETE APPROACH SLAB WITH QC/QA (T=__), AS PER PLAN. Examples of non-standard approach slabs include approach slabs that are: a non-standard length; tapered; curved; a non-uniform width or other such variation. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-235 310.2.2 292BSTANDARD BRIDGE DRAWING – AS-2-15 C310.2.2 Standard Bridge Drawing, AS-2-15, provides contract ready installation details for standard approach slabs. Refer to the Designer Supplement to AS-2-15 for additional information. 310.3 105BPRESSURE RELIEF JOINTS C310.3 When the approach roadway pavement is rigid concrete and the approach slab Installation is Type C, specify a Type B pressure relief joints at a location 50-ft from the end of the sleeper slab. Alternatively, a 25-ft length of full depth asphalt pavement may be specified between the sleeper slab and the rigid pavement. The pressure relief joints are detailed on Standard Construction Drawing BP-2.4, Pressure Relief Joint Types B, C, & D. 310.4 106BUTILITIES C310.4 Make the request to allow utilities on the bridge through the ODOT District Utilities Coordinator. Install utilities in substantial ducts or enclosures adequate to protect the lines from future bridge repair and maintenance operations. The type of superstructure selected for a site may be dependent upon the number of utilities supported on the bridge. Do not place utilities inside of prestressed concrete box beams. If the bridge design is a composite deck on prestressed box beams, the design may either eliminate an interior box beam or provide a space between two interior box beams to provide utility access in this space. This alternative will require a special design for both the box beams and the deck. When it is necessary to place a utility, storm sewer trunk line, or culvert through, beneath or within a 10-ft radius of the limits of the select granular backfill of an MSE wall, encase it in steel casing pipe according to C&MS 748.06. Placing utilities, storm sewers and culverts through, beneath or within a 10-ft radius of the select granular backfill of an MSE wall should be avoided. When it is necessary to place a storm sewer within the limits of the select granular backfill of an MSE wall, provide reinforced concrete pipe according to C&MS 706.02. Provide premium joints according to C&MS 706.11 and wrap the pipe joints in geotextile fabric, Type A according to C&MS 712.09. Show and dimension utility conduits embedded in concrete to clear construction joints by a minimum of 1-in and other conduits by a minimum of 2-in. Do not embedded utilities in the actual vehicular traffic carrying section of a concrete deck. Do not suspend utilities below the bottom of the bridge superstructure or attach directly to the deck. For approval procedures for installation of utilities on bridges, please refer to ODOT's Utilities Manual. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-236 310.4.1 293BUTILITIES ATTACHED TO BEAMS AND GIRDERS C310.4.1 Do not place utility lines between the stringers in the exterior bays of grade separation structures. This is to protect the lines from collisions. Locate critical utility lines (gas, etc.) that could contribute to the severity of a collision well above the bottom of the superstructure or be otherwise protected. 310.5 107BAESTHETICS 310.5.1 294BGENERAL C310.5.1 Refer to the ODOT Aesthetic Design Guidelines for aesthetics treatments on structures. Each structure should be evaluated for aesthetics. Normally it is not practical to provide cost premium aesthetic treatments without a specific demand; however careful attention to the details of the structure lines and forms will generally result in a pleasing structure appearance. Some basic guidelines that should be considered are as follows: A. Avoid mixing structural elements, for example concrete slab and steel beam superstructures or cap and column piers with wall type piers. B. In general, continuous superstructures shall be provided for multiple span bridges. Where intermediate joints cannot be avoided, the depth of spans adjacent to the joints preferably should be the same. Avoid the use of very slender superstructures over massive piers. C. Abrupt changes in beam depth should be avoided when possible. Whenever sudden changes in the depth of the beams in adjacent spans are required, care should be taken in the development of details at the pier. D. The lines of the structure should be simple and without excessive curves and abrupt changes. E. All structures should blend in with their surroundings. The most significant design factors contributing to the aesthetic quality of the structure is unity, consistency, and continuity. These qualities will give the structure an appearance of a design process that was carefully thought out. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-237 The aesthetics of the structure can generally be accomplished within the guidelines of design requiring only minimum special designs and minor project cost increase. If formliners are being considered, the depth of the projections should be as deep as possible in order to have the desired visual effect. Using shallow depths, such as 2-in to 3-in, provides very little, if any, visual effect (relief) when viewed from a distance. The depth of the formliner shall not be included in the measurement of the concrete clear cover. The use of colored concrete, where the color is integral with the concrete mix, should generally not be used since the final visual appearance of the concrete is not uniform. The color varies greatly due to the aggregate, cement type, cement content and the curing of the concrete. None of these items are reasonably controlled in the field to a sufficient enough degree to ensure a uniform final appearance. If color is required, a concrete coating should be used which will not only produce the required color but will also provide the necessary sealing of the concrete as required in BDM Sections 306.1.2 and 309.2.1. The use of formliners and/or coloring of the concrete should be evaluated on a cost basis and submitted as part of the Structure Type Study, Cost Analysis. 310.5.2 295BLETTERING AND LOGO POLICY ON ODOT FACILITIES C310.5.2 Obtain approval from the Office of Structural Engineering for all lettering and logos to be placed on a bridge. Obtain approval from the Office of Environmental Services for all lettering and logos to be placed on noise walls. Obtain approval from the Division of Innovative Delivery for all lettering and logos to be placed on ODOT facilities through sponsorship naming proposals. Office of Structural Engineering approval of a lettering and logo submission does not constitute acceptance of the structural design. Structural design acceptance will occur through the review processes defined in BDM Section 200. Aesthetic lighting shall be in accordance with the ODOT TEM note 1142-26. The owner of the bridge should consider obtaining a written agreement regarding operating costs and maintenance responsibilities with local agency requesting the lettering or logo enhancements. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-238 The criteria for permitting lettering and logos on Bridges and Noise Walls is as follows: A. City names and City logos are acceptable provided the bridge or noise wall is within the territorial jurisdiction of that City. B. County names and County logos are acceptable provided the bridge or noise wall is within the territorial jurisdiction of that County. C. Street names and Path names are acceptable provided the bridge carries that public street or public path. Private street names or private path names are not permissible. D. Obtain FHWA acceptance, if necessary. The local agency requesting the lettering or logo may be required to fund the additional cost over what ODOT would normally install on the bridge or noise wall. A. ODOT traditionally uses standard concrete form liners on bridges and noise walls. If the lettering or logo will require additional or custom concrete form liners, the cost over a standard concrete form liner may be required to be secured/funded by the local agency. B. ODOT traditionally places vandal protection fencing on bridges. If the lettering or logo will require non-standard fence or supports, the cost over the standard fence may be required to be secured/funded by the local agency. E. Lettering or logos shall not extend above the top of bridge railing or fence. Lettering or logos shall not extend below the normal lines of the bridge superstructure. F. Lettering or logos on bridge substructure units shall be within the normal limits of those units. Do not add extraneous elements for the sole purpose of displaying lettering or logos. G. Provide 5 copies of rendering(s) of the proposal with the request. 310.6 108BRAILWAY BRIDGES C310.6 Contact the Ohio Rail Development Commission (ORDC) for assistance with railroad-roadway coordination including overpass design requirements. Ohio's largest railroads, CSX and Norfolk Southern, publish Public Project Manuals to assist public entities in interacting with their organizations. Regional and short-line railroads often publish information on their websites to identify appropriate processes and contacts. Links to CSX and Norfolk Southern Public Project Manuals are available on the ORDC website. For railway overpasses the specific requirements of the railway company involved need to be addressed. The design and operational requirements of the railway companies will vary from railway line to railway line and between companies. Some of the common railway concerns are as follows: A. Horizontal and vertical clearances for both the final proposed design and during construction, B. The constructability of the substructure units adjacent to their tracks, C. Allowing adequate clearances for drainage ditches and access roads that are parallel to their tracks, D. Location of railway utilities, and E. Provisions for crash walls on piers. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-239 Drainage from the bridge should be collected in drain pipes and drained away from the railway right of way When temporary shoring details are required for construction of substructure units adjacent to railway tracks, include details in the plans. When considering excavation for substructure units, address whether sheet piling can be driven (avoid existing footing, clear any battered piles, elevation of bedrock, etc.) and whether the proper lengths can be provided to retain the railway tracks. Do not allow settlement of the tracks to occur. Interlocking sheet piling of cantilever design is preferred. It may be appropriate to leave the temporary shoring in place after construction. 310.7 109B ICYCLE BRIDGES C310.7 For new structures, the minimum bridge width shall be the same as the width of the paved bicycle path and approach shoulders. Use a minimum transverse slope of 1/4 in per foot sloped in one direction. Provide bicycle railings at a minimum of 3.5-ft high. For the design of the railing refer to AASHTO LRFD Article 13.9. If an occasional maintenance vehicle is going to use the bridge, design the railing as only a bicycle railing. Use bicycle safe bridge deck joints. Refer to the ODOT publication, Bicycle and Pedestrian Resources for Engineers, for more information and resource references. If a timber deck is used, apply a 1-1/2-in minimum thickness of ITEM 441 - ASPHALT CONCRETE SURFACE COURSE, TYPE 1, PG64-22, in order to provide an abrasive skid resistant surface. Other alternative surfaces may be used if approved by the Department. 310.8 110BPEDESTRIAN BRIDGES C310.8 Meet the grade and cross slope requirements specified in L&D, Vol. 1, Section 306.2.5 for pedestrian facilities. For pedestrian bridges over highways, provide an additional one foot of vertical clearance. If a timber deck is used, apply a 1.5-in minimum thickness of ITEM 441 - ASPHALT CONCRETE SURFACE COURSE, TYPE 1, PG64-22, in order to provide an abrasive skid resistant surface. Other alternative surfaces may be used if approved by the Department. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-240 310.9 111BMAINTENANCE AND INSPECTION ACCESS C310.9 Maintenance and inspection access requirements should be included in the Structure Type Study, Narrative of Bridge Alternatives. For multiple span bridges with 8-ft or deeper girders, an inspection handrail located on the girders should be provided. Catwalks should also be considered. Safety cables and other fall arrest systems should be considered in addition to handrails and catwalks. Provisions for maintenance and inspection access should be provided for fracture critical girders, cross girders and bents that cannot be inspected from a snooper. The use of fracture critical members is strongly discouraged. For these types of structures, consult the Office of Structural Engineering for details and recommendations. Additional information is provided in “FHWA Guidelines for Providing Access to Bridges for Inspections”, dated November 1985. 310.10 112BSIGN SUPPORTS C310.10 Make every effort to locate overhead sign supports off bridge structures. When this is not possible, only two locations on the structure are acceptable and are listed below in order of preference: Research has shown that overhead sign supports located on bridges are highly susceptible to fatigue damage. A. Mounted directly to the substructure unit. B. Mounted to the superstructure directly over a substructure unit. Underpass sign supports attached to the fascia of overpass bridges, as shown on Plan Insert Sheets: PIS 201824 and PIS 201826, should also be avoided. Consult with the District Bridge Engineer before specifying their use. 310.11 113BSTRUCTURAL GROUNDING & LIGHTING C310.11 Provide structural grounding for the following structures: A. Structures with metal railing B. Structures with fencing C. Structures carrying electrical utilities or have overhead electrical utilities. See Sections 1140 and 1150 of the TEM for additional information. Provide underpass or tunnel lighting as required by Section 1103-6.9 of the TEM. 311 18B URIED STRUCTURES For hydraulic design, foundation and scour requirements, refer to the L&D Vol 2. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-241 The structural design of buried structure components shall be in accordance with the latest edition of the AASHTO LRFD Bridge Design Specifications. 311.1 114BHALF-HEIGHT HEADWALLS C311.1 For buried structures that utilize half-height headwalls, provide a pay item for ITEM 602 – CONCRETE MASONRY. C&MS 602.03.D permits the Contractor to use precast concrete for circular conduits up to a maximum of 78-in and elliptical and pipe arch conduits up to a maximum 78-in round equivalent. For corrugated metal pipe and plastic pipe, provide a reference to Standard Bridge Drawing HW-2.1. For concrete pipe, provide a reference to Standard Bridge Drawing HW-2.2. For non-standard half-height headwalls, provide the complete details in the Plans. 311.2 115BFULL-HEIGHT HEADWALLS 311.2.1 296BCIRCULAR, ELLIPTICAL AND PIPE ARCH STRUCTURES C311.2.1 For circular, elliptical and pipe arch buried structures utilizing full-height headwalls, provide a pay item for ITEM 602 – CONCRETE MASONRY. The Department will not permit the use of precast concrete structures for these types of full-height headwalls. Provide a reference to Standard Bridge Drawing HW-1.1 when applicable. For non-standard full-height headwalls, provide the complete details in the Plans. 311.2.2 297BPRECAST CONCRETE BOX, FLAT TOPPED, ARCH & ROUND SECTIONS C311.2.2 Use one of the following methods of Plan preparation for projects with precast concrete box, C&MS 706.05; three-sided flat topped, C&MS 706.051; arch, C&MS 706.052; and round, C&MS 706.053: The selection of a Plan preparation strategy for full-height headwalls for these structure types should occur during project scoping. Projects with time-sensitive closure periods in the construction schedule should consider precast full-height headwalls. Refer to BDM Figure 311-1 for an illustration of headwall component terminology. A. Cast-in-place full-height headwalls The Contractor will not have an option in the C&MS to provide precast structures for cast-in-place full-height headwalls. These would need to be considered according to C&MS 105.19 Value Engineering Change Proposals. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-242
  33. Provide cubic yard pay items for ITEM 511 – CLASS QC1 CONCRETE, HEADWALL; ITEM 511 – CLASS QC1 CONCRETE, RETAINING/WINGWALL NOT INCLUDING FOOTING; and ITEM 511 – CLASS QC1 CONCRETE, FOOTING.
  34. Provide Plan and Elevation views of the headwalls showing wingwalls, foreslope walls, and footings including cutoff walls at each end of the conduit detailing all wall dimensions, angles and elevations.
  35. Provide Plan, Elevation and Section views of the headwalls showing wingwalls, foreslope walls, and footings including cutoff walls detailing all reinforcement locations and bar marks.
  36. Provide a schedule of concrete reinforcement for all bars in the wingwalls, foreslope walls, and footings including cutoff walls. For precast concrete box structures, C&MS 706.05, refer to the Design Data Sheet for Concrete Headwalls for Precast Box Culverts for complete designs; to the Plan Insert Sheets for Precast Concrete Box Culverts for pre-detailed Plan sheets; and to Design Data Sheet HWDD_Rebar for concrete reinforcement bar list development. For additional information regarding Plan content for drainage structures, refer to the Sample Plans and the L&D, Vol. 3 provided on the Office of CADD and Mapping Services webpage. B. Precast full-height headwalls Do not use precast headwalls where the angle between the centerline of the waterway and the exposed face of the wall is less than 30-degrees. Contractors are required to select precast gravity or semigravity retaining wall systems preapproved by the Office of Geotechnical Engineering for full-height headwalls paid for with SS851.
  37. Provide pay items for: a. ITEM 851 (SQUARE FOOT) – PRECAST GRAVITY AND SEMIGRAVITY RETAINING WALL b. ITEM 851 (DAYS) – ON-SITE ASSISTANCE c. ITEM 851 (LUMP SUM) – PGSRW INSPECTION AND COMPACTION TESTING The pay items listed here are the intended as the minimal items necessary to install the headwall structures. Additional items (e.g. Structure Removed, Cofferdams and Excavation Bracing, Sealing of Concrete Surfaces, etc.) should be included as necessary for each project. The Department will consider all PEJF required for the precast wall installation to be included in the payment for the wall. Refer to the Designer Note for SS851 for more information regarding the use of the pay items listed. There are additional pay items provided in SS851 not listed herein because they may not be applicable for all buried structure applications or may be paid elsewhere under separate pay items (e.g. Embankment, Using Natural Soils, 703.16A, 6” drainage pipe, etc.). d. ITEM 851 (LUMP SUM) – WALL DRAINAGE SYSTEM This pay item includes all backfill, filter fabric, prefabricated geocomposite drains, pipes and pipe outlets required to drain the precast walls. e. ITEM 503 (CUBIC YARD) – UNCLASSIFIED EXCAVATION This pay item is intended for excavation to install the conduit footings and wingwalls. f. ITEM 509 (POUND) – EPOXY COATED STEEL REINFORCEMENT Include the reinforcement detailed in the footings, cutoff walls, closure pour and foreslope walls only. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-243 g. ITEM 511 (CUBIC YARD) – CLASS QC1 CONCRETE, FOOTING Include concrete in the footings, cutoff walls and closure pours only. h. ITEM 511 (CUBIC YARD) – CLASS QC1 CONCRETE, HEADWALL Provide a plan notes clarifying that this quantity represents the foreslope wall located atop each end of the conduit. i. ITEM 518 (CUBIC YARD) – POROUS BACKFILL WITH FILTER FABRIC
  38. Provide Plan, Elevation and Section views of the headwalls showing wingwalls, foreslope walls and footings including cutoff walls at each end of the conduit detailing all wall dimensions, angles and elevations. In the Plan view, show the location of the outside face of the wall. For wall designs under SS851, the Contractor will be responsible for providing the structural design and detailing of all precast walls including modifications to the footings necessary to accommodate the precast walls. The Designer is responsible for providing a fully detailed footing and assumed wall face location that will satisfy foundation design requirements of BDM Section 305 and fit within the construction limits and other constraints required at the site. For the foundation stability analyses, assume a wall stem thickness equal to that used in Standard Bridge Drawings HW-1.1 or HWDD-1, as applicable, for the type of culvert being constructed. For additional information regarding Plan content for drainage structures, refer to the Sample Plans and the L&D, Vol. 3 provided on the Office of CADD and Mapping Services webpage. For precast concrete box structures, C&MS 706.05, refer to the Design Data Sheet for Concrete Headwalls for Precast Box Culverts to detail wall and footing geometry. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-244 Figure 311-1 312 19BREDUNDANCY C312 The purpose of this section is to provide policy and commentary for the classification of members as redundant or non-redundant. When members are deemed to not have load path redundancy, the sections concerning system redundancy and internal redundancy offer options on how to redesignate members previously classified as an NSTM. These provisions may be utilized to analyze and designate of both existing and proposed members. For additional information regarding the inspection requirements of these members, refer to the Ohio Manual of Bridge Inspection (OMBI). BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-245 Historically, only load path redundancy has been considered when determining a member’s redundancy and subsequent design, fabrication and inspection requirements. However, two additional forms of redundancy were introduced in the National Bridge Inspection Standards (NBIS) in 2022. These new classifications for redundancy afford designers the ability to characterize steel tension members that would have previously been considered nonredundant as redundant if it can be proven, through analysis, that the member is redundant. This section will cover the necessary resources and analysis procedures required to determine a member’s redundancy in terms of load path redundant, system redundant, internally redundant, or nonredundant The NBIS defines Load Path, System, and Internal Redundancy as follows: Load Path Redundancy: A redundancy exists based on the number of primary load-carrying members such that fracture of the cross section at one location of a member will not cause a portion of or the entire bridge to collapse. System Redundancy: A redundancy that exists in a bridge system without load path redundancy, such that fracture of the cross section at one location of a primary member will not cause a portion of or the entire bridge to collapse. Internal Redundancy: A redundancy that exists within a primary member cross-section without load path redundancy, such that fracture of one component will not propagate through the entire member, is discoverable by the applicable inspection procedures, and will not cause a portion of or the entire bridge to collapse. The NBIS also defines Nonredundant Steel Tension Member (NSTM) as follows: NSTM: A primary steel member fully or partially in tension, and without load path redundancy, system redundancy or internal redundancy, whose failure may cause a portion of or the entire bridge to collapse. 312.1 116BLOAD PATH REDUNDANCY For the strength limit state only, apply a redundancy load modifier (ηR) equal to 1.05 for all elements and components designated as non-redundant. For elements and components designated as redundant, apply a redundancy load modifier (ηR) equal to 1.00 for all limit states. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-246 For superstructure types (a) and (k), as defined in LRFD Table 4.6.2.2.1-1, consider the primary members as nonredundant when the superstructure consists of less than three girder lines. For superstructure types (a) and (k), as defined in LRFD Table 4.6.2.2.1-1, consider the primary members as nonredundant when the superstructure consists of three longitudinal girder lines spaced greater than 16-ft. For superstructure types (a) and (k), as defined in LRFD Table 4.6.2.2.1-1, consider the primary members as redundant when the superstructure consists of three longitudinal girder lines spaced at 16-ft or less or four or more longitudinal girder lines regardless of spacing. 312.2 117BFRACTURE CONTROL FOR STEEL MEMBERS C312.2 All steel members without load path redundancy, as defined in BDM Section 312.1, shall be subjected to fabrication Fracture Control regardless of the member designation. Identify these members in the plans as “FC”. If a member has been designated as system redundant member (SRM) or an internally redundant member (IRM), fracture control is still required for fabrication. Refer to LRFD 6.6.2.2 for additional information on the designation requirements for the plans. Until a steel member without load path redundancy, as defined in BDM Section 312.2, has been redesignated to be a system redundant member (SRM) or an internally redundant member (IRM), follow the provisions of BDM Section 312.2 for the load modifier in the design. The redundancy load modifier (ηR) may be taken as 1.0 for members that have redesignated as SRMs or IRMs. 312.3 118BMEMBER REDESIGNATION When evaluating an NSTM element for redesignation as either a SRM or IRM, use one of the following guide specifications: 1. AASHTO Guide Specification for Analysis and Identification of Fracture Critical Members and System Redundant Members (GSFCM-1-UL) 2. AASHTO Guide Specification for Internal Redundancy of Mechanically-Fastened Built-Up Members (GSBSM-1-UL) Do not consider any of the following NSTM elements in a redundancy analysis for SRM or IRM redesignation.
  • Pins
  • Hangers
  • Eyebars When investigating an existing NSTM element for a redundancy analysis, all the following conditions need to be met to for the NSTM element to be eligible. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-247
  • Existing structure has undergone a NSTM inspection within the past 24 months.
  • No plug welds or discontinuous back-up bar splices
  • No fatigue cracks
  • No impact damage
  • No load posting
  • No element level condition state 4 on the NSTM member This criterion is only applicable on bridges that receive element level inspections.
  • The member under consideration does not warrant an NSTM component condition rating of 6 or less. The objective of this provision is to allow an analysis of an individual NSTM member in good condition when the structure may have an overall NSTM component condition rating of fair or poor.
  • Not susceptible to constraint induced fracture Refer to Publication No. FHWA-HIF-21-046: Evaluation of Steel Bridge Details for Susceptibility to Constraint-Induced Fracture for additional information. 312.3.1 298BSYSTEM REDUNDANCY C312.3.1 Use a nationally recognized method to evaluate a member as a SRM in lieu of NSTM. If required, conduct a three-dimensional finite element system analysis (FEA) to classify a member as a SRM in lieu of NSTM. The software used to perform the FEA shall meet the minimum requirements in Section 3.1.1 of GSFCM-1-UL. If a method other than FEA is chosen for the redesignation analysis, this method shall be approved by the Office of Structural Engineering prior to the analysis. Meet all applicable requirements presented in Sections 4, 5, 6, and 7 of GSFCM-1-UL in the FEA. Guidance on Material Models, Meshing Requirements, Interactions, Constraints, Application of Loads, and Boundary Conditions are given in Sections 4, 5, 6, and 7 of GSFCM-1-UL. Consider all applicable failure scenarios outlined in Section 3.1.3 of GSFCM-1-UL in the FEA. 312.3.1.1 481BLOADS & LOAD COMBINATIONS Use the provisions of GSFCM-1-UL to investigate two distinct redundancy load combinations. For each redundancy load combination, apply the total load, Qu, calculated using the following equation: Qu = (1 + DAR)[γDCDC + γDWDW + γLL(LL + IM)] Where: γ = Load factor DC = Dead load of structural components and nonstructural attachments BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-248 DW = Dead load of wearing surfaces and utilities LL = Vehicular live load DAR = Dynamic amplification factor IM = Vehicular dynamic allowance If bridge members were fabricated using the AASHTO/AWS D1.5 FCP use the load factors presented in BDM Table 312-1. Table 312-1: Bridge Members Fabricated using AASHTO/AWS D1.5 FCP Load Combination γDC γDC γDC DA- IM Redundancy I 1.05 1.05 0.85 0.40 0.00 Redundancy II 1.05 1.05 1.30 0.00 0.15 If bridge members were not fabricated using the AASHTO/AWS D1.5 FCP use the load factors presented in BDM Table 312-2. Table 312-2: Bridge Members Not Fabricated using AASHTO/AWS D1.5 FCP Load Combination γDC γDC γDC DAR IM Redundancy I 1.15 1.25 1.00 0.40 0.00 Redundancy II 1.15 1.25 1.50 0.00 0.15 Dead loads for proposed structures shall consist of all gravity loads, including future loads. Apply dead loads as body forces. For existing structures, apply only the dead loads present on the structure at the time of analysis. A new analysis will be required when the loading on the bridge changes. Refer to BDM Section 914 for a list of loading changes that warrants a new analysis. Live Loads shall consist of the HL-93 vehicular live load as defined in LRFD Section 3.6.1.2. Apply the live loads in each load combination as described below. Redundancy I: This is the load combination relating to a point-in-time live load applied at the instant when the assumed failure of the member occurs. The intent of this loading scenario is to capture the effects of dynamic amplification immediately following the member failure.
  • The number of lanes is the number of striped travel lanes only. Center the live load at the center of the striped lanes. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-249 Redundancy II: This is the load combination relating to normal vehicular use of the bridge without wind after the failure of a primary member. The intent of this load combination is to capture the loading after the fracture has occurred and the structure has reached a steady state.
  • Use LRFD Section 3.6.1.1.1 to determine the number of lanes. Position the lanes transversely to produce the largest demand on the remaining unfractured components. 312.3.2 299BITERNAL REDUNDANCY C312.3.2 The GSBSM-1-UL groups similar types of built-up members into flexural, two-component axial, and multi-component axial. Flexural members are bolted girders or beams with at least one tension cover plate. Two-component axial members are composed of only two steel sections bolted together so if one section fails, the other will take the full load. Multi-component axial members are composed of 3 or more steel sections bolted together and providing multiple load paths if one section fails. Evaluate members at the worst-case stress locations for each individual cross section configuration in the faulted state for strength in accordance with the guide specifications. Any location or cross section of a member failing the strength check in the faulted state is not eligible to be classified as internally redundant. For members passing the strength checks in the faulted state, evaluate fatigue for both unfaulted and faulted states to gain an understanding of the potential life of the member before a fatigue crack may form. Calculate inspection intervals based on the fatigue life in accordance with the Guide Specifications based on the analysis results. Inspection intervals are likely to differ along the bridge at each cross section analyzed. For each structure, the owner will determine if the critical locations will all be inspected at the lowest inspection interval allowed or if inspection intervals at each location will be based on what is allowed per the analysis. Fatigue may be evaluated using field measured effective stress ranges at the desired cross sections in the structure to potentially obtain more favorable fatigue life calculations. 312.3.3 300BPERFORMANCE IN THE FAULTED STATE To determine if an existing or new steel tension member without load path redundancy can be designated as a SRM or an IRM in lieu of NSTM can be redesignated as SRM or IRM in lieu of NSTM, the member shall meet performance criteria developed to establish the minimum acceptable performance level in the faulted state. BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-250 These elements shall meet all applicable Strength, Service, and Extreme Event requirements detailed in AASHTO LRFD Bridge Design Specification and this manual. For designation as SRM, meet the Performance Criteria detailed in Section 8 of GSFCM-1-UL, except as noted in this manual. Section 8.2.1 of the GSFCM-1-UL requires an analysis with the live load at a 15% increase, this shall apply only to existing members being investigated for redesignated. Proposed members being designated as SRM shall be designed to remain linearly elastic at all load combinations. For designation of existing members as IRM, designs shall meet the Performance Criteria detailed in Section 2 of GSBSM-1-UL. Proposed members being designated as IRM shall be designed to remain linearly elastic at all load combinations. 312.3.4 301BSUBMITAL REQUIREMENTS When designating existing members or designing proposed SRMs or IRMs, submit the following information with the plans as an independent report: Stage 1 Plan Submittal:
  • Nationally recognized method intended for use for determining redundancy.
  • Engineer to be overseeing the analysis and their experience with regards to Steel Design, Finite Element Modeling, and any other relevant experience.
  • The software or computation method intended for the evaluation redundancy. (System Redundancy Analysis requires FEA modeling)
  • The Expected Special inspection interval Stage 2 Plan Submittal:
  • Nationally recognized method used for determining redundancy.
  • Engineer that oversaw the analysis and their experience with regards to Steel Design, Finite Element Modeling, and any other relevant experience.
  • Engineer who performed the Technical Quality Review and their associated experience.
  • The software or computation method used for the redundancy evaluation. (System Redundancy Analysis require FEA modeling) BDM Section 300 – Detail Design 2020 Edition – January 2025 3-251
  • A summary of the results of the analysis.
  • The recommended special inspection interval.
  • Any additional requirements that should be added to the routine inspection of the structure. (i.e. Access considerations or Areas of focus)
  • Site specific requirements for the special inspection needed to determine if a fracture has occurred and to potentially find damage that could affect the structural integrity.
  • Criteria to define when the member would default back to an NSTM.
  • A comprehensive Calculation Package shall be included in the Final Calculation Submittal. 312.3.4.1 482BSPECIAL REQUIREMENTS FOR THREE-GIRDER STRADDLE BENTS Stacked Three-Grider Straddle bents are load path redundant. Stacked Three-Grider Straddle Bents, where the longitudinal girders are “stacked” on top of the Straddle Bent, and a bearing is provided under each I-girder web comprising the straddle, have been nationally recognized as having load path redundancy and no system redundancy analysis is required. The analysis may consider all bracing, continuous framed girders, deck (and all reinforcement), and continuous concrete barriers as being effective for load transfer. Integral straddle bents, where the longitudinal girders frame into the side of the straddle bent, will need to be analyzed for system redundancy regardless of the number of bearings that are used under the beam. Consider fractures at points of maximum load effects at the Strength I load combination in the analysis. If only one bearing is used under the straddle bent, show that the load transfer to the single bearing can be maintained by adding more fracture analysis cases to diaphragms or other critical members as may be necessary. These high stress values may occur for symmetrically loaded simple supported members at midspan and near the support of one of the exterior girders of the three-girder system. When the three-girder straddle bent is subjected to the dead load portion of the Redundancy II load combination in the faulted state, the primary steel members with any tension shall be designated as NSTMs if the straddle cap experiences a maximum vertical deflection larger than L/50. January 2025 4-iii 404.1 STRUCTURAL STEEL .................................................................................................................. 4-41 404.1.1 DAMAGE OR SECTION LOSS ................................................................................. 4-80 406.1 ADHESIVE ANCHOR/DOWEL DESIGN .................................................................................... 4-80 BDM Section 400 –Rehabilitation and Maintenance 2020 Edition – January 2025 4-vi (THIS PAGE WAS INTENTIONALLY LEFT BLANK) BDM Section 400 –Rehabilitation and Maintenance 2020 Edition – January 2025 4-1 SECTION 400 – REHABILITATION AND MAINTENANCE 401 20BINTRODUCTION BDM Sections 100, 200 & 300 apply for the design of Rehabilitation and Maintenance to existing bridges except as noted in BDM Section 100. Refer to BDM Section 101 for a description of the format, audience, purpose and more related to this Manual. 401.1 119BGENERAL CONSIDERATIONS C401.1 Perform a site visit to the structure and identify/verify defects that may exist, in order to tailor solutions to all problems found. During this site visit, take color photographs and develop sketches showing pertinent details and field verified dimensions. Schedule this visit during the plan development phase of the project. For individual members, determine whether the best option is to repair or replace. In making this decision, consider cost along with factors such as traffic maintenance, convenience to the public, longevity of the structure, whether the rehab is long term or short term, and the practicality of all options. Verify all pertinent field dimensions. Do not to take dimensions directly from old plans without checking them in the field because deviations from plans are common. The Designer is responsible for providing accurate bid information based on field observations and preparing plans that reflect the actual field conditions. Under C&MS 105.02, the Contractor is responsible for taking measurements of existing structures to accurately join new and existing work.
